RoMeCz2tmou-xteml9TODQ.text: In a nutshell: A fine-dining establishment that is not really unique, with decent over-priced food.   We went here for friend's birthday. She loves foie gras so I would say that her experience was probably 5 stars. However, for me and bf, it was just okay. Let me start off by saying I LOVE fancy restaurants. I think an awesome fancy restaurant is completely worth spending a ton of money when the food is phenomenal, and IMHO, Sage was not that.  BF and I got the prix fix Signature menu, which is about $90 a person. With that, we received a starter of beef tartar and oysters. The egg on the beef tartar was nearly cooked through, so it was hard to mix it up with the beef. The oysters were nothing special and very small. Our next course was a scallop each. The scallop was the highlight of our meal. It was perfectly cooked and seasoned and was just delicious. It comes with a bite of short rib, which was the perfect compliment to the scallop.  For the 3rd course, I ordered the sirloin and BF got the pork loin. One of our friends at the table also ordered the pork loin, but not on the Signature menu. The dish is actually 1 part pork loin and the other part a sausage of some sort. Her portion was TWICE the size of his. His was basically 2 bites of pork and a piece of sausage. They both said it was just okay. My sirloin was good but completely over sauced. I love steak in its simplicity and feel that good piece of meat that is cooked well doesn't need to be drenched in sauce.  All of the desserts, with the exception of my friend's $20 foie gras candy bar dessert, were completely underwhelming. I would've preferred to stop at DQ on the way home. The foie gras candy bar was gold flaked and fancy. Because of how rich and decadent it was, it's a perfect dessert to share. It was yummy!  All in all, it was as I said, OK. But if I'm gonna spend that kind of money, I want to be WOW'd and blown away by the food,and unfortunately, I was far from it. :(

gwWKNFcz7orOjszLq-2eJw.text: Loved the whole experience and the food was delicious! We had the hamachi crudo, the lamb paperdelle and the black cod and they were all amazing!

snOzL-NmZwCfE3BRX9brmA.text: Sage was amazing! The food was perfect and it had a nice ambiance although it was still casual. The prices of the drinks are a bit high, but they're damn good. They also have absinthe fountains in case you're interested.   If you don't choose to go for the tasting, you can go for 2,3, or 4 course options. Everything is great. If you're a wagyu fan the supplementary cost is worth it. The scallops as a main were epic. Dessert was creative and yummy (it's on a separate menu), so save room.     Our server may have cracked one too many jokes but hey, at least he was nice.

PiKJTcWU23JMLW26Q0emeA.text: The chef at this place knows what he is doing.  The food was good.   I disagree with pampering already delicious foie gras with citrus and bunch of other flavors but respect this as a choice the chef has made. It was interesting.  The presentation of each dish was great.   The reason for two stars is the bus boy who was extremely sloppy, almost rude. Things like spilling water when pouring and not wiping it up or slamming silverware on the table, moving around in a very abrupt and almost offensive way spoiled my impression of this place.   The management needs to invest in training personnel. No matter how good the food may be - if you are in a service industry - learn how to provide quality service.   I will not recommend this place to anyone just because the service was poor. There are plenty of places in Vegas that have great food and know how to provide proper customer service.

GzBAc-UfVuxjnl_45PDrfg.text: I had an outstanding meal last night at Sage. The space is beautiful yet warm and inviting. Romantic. My server, John, could not have been better. Very professional, yet friendly, with superb recommendations. He was terrific. I wish I knew the name of the gentleman helping him, with bread, water and the like... he also could not have been better. (The staff across the board, from the hostesses to the food runners were all wonderful.)  And the food! I was bowled over by the flavors with every dish. I did 3 courses: 2 appetizers and one entree. The first was an artichoke and fennel salad: both were shaved mandoline thin, beautifully arranged with crispy capers (wow), various citrus and goat cheese. The flavors were remarkable. Then I had roasted heirloom beets and carrots, with various purees, including an intense, amazing tarragon pesto and the surprise was bitter chocolate, burnt and crumbled. I almost did not order this because of the chocolate but the way it worked in the dish was incredible. Again, fresh, deep, amazing flavors.   For my entree, I had lamb: perfectly cooked (and I mean PERFECT) lamb loin, with a rich eggplant puree, the best snap peas I've ever eaten and a lamb neck tureen. Again, I was a little iffy on the tureen but it was incredible and very inventive. It looked the way bone marrow is served, yet what is usually the bone was the actual neck, crisped and delicious, with a decadent compote of lamb and other ingredients inside. It's not as weird as it sounds, it was just plain delicious. I don't know where these snap peas came from but fresh doesn't even begin to describe them.   All in all, one of the best meals I have had in a while. I started with a top notch Manhattan and John recommended two perfect wines, a sancerre with the appetizers and a cotes du rhone with the lamb.

oryvb3QE5sFm21EAr0QVSA.text: First of all, please note the dollar signs associated with this restaurant. This place is REALLY pricey. We ate here on a holiday weekend and I really expected the place to be more crowded but there were like 3 other parties in the entire restaurant, which, in my opinion, makes the place look bad. One of the parties had 2 small children which were crying and running around and it really pissed me off that we were paying so much to eat at such a fancy establishment and not one worker addressed the out-of-control kids.  Anyway, on to the food. I found the dinner to be average in taste (in comparison to the price). The best thing was the dessert. We each ordered a separate dessert and they were AMAZING. The dessert was well worth the cost. Otherwise, I won't be back.

mUnWfTACkrCgO6P2CEWILg.text: I really wanted to like sage, but the food and service made that a little hard. Don't get me wrong, it wasn't terrible, but for the price point I expected a lot more. As soon as we were seated our waiter stopped by to drop off our menus and told us they were "self explanatory". We didn't see much of him after that. My wife and I both wanted the three course dinner, but there were 4 sections to order from. We were confused about which sections we should make our selections from. Not as "self explanatory" as our waiter made it seem. Luckily a nice lady in a suit stopped by to take our drink orders and helped to explain the menu to us. We would rely on her and the friendly bus boy for most of the night.           As for the food, it was not terrible but we found the quality was not up to par with the other restaurants in Las Vegas at this price range.  *Amuse-bouche- tuna tartare was the best thing we ate that night. It was delicious *First course - The Slow Poached Farm Egg was average, nothing to write home about.  *The Alaskan King Crab was also average. Decent, but not exciting.  *Second course - The Foie Gras Brulee was my favorite course. Rich and flavorful, just a little         sweeter than i usually like my Foie gras.   *The Grilled Spanish Octopus was smokey and flavored well, however the octopus was dense and just not a pleasant texture. The spinach underneath was also extremely overdressed  *Third Course - The Maine Day Boat Scallops were also dissapointing. I found caramel                        reduction very sweet and overpowering. My wife had a fish dish which was also fairly dull. We also ordered a glass of absinthe from the nice lady in the suit. We think she was either a manager or the sommelier. The absinthe was delicious, one of the high points of the night.        As far as fine dining in Las Vegas goes, i feel that sage has a ways to go. If i were to spend over $100 per person, I could think of quite a few restaurants in las vegas i would rather dine at.

hhmnZNZkpLKAtFvwx7wAlA.text: Sage came highly recommended (form the somellier at L'Atelier de Joel Robuchon) Needless to say we we're very excited about this place.  1. Great open floor plan and huge restaurant  2. Wonderful service as you would expect from a fine dining place 3. Good pace for the courses 4. Excellent bourbon selection (didn't really look at the wine list) 5. We ordered three full tasting meals and three of the small versions. So, we got to taste everything. All in all good, but a place like this needs to blow us away like Joel Robuchon always does. The best dish was the braised veal and the chefs signature dish was the scallop and it was good but not great.  6. The chestnut soup gets at thumbs up from everybody. Again I'm tough on restaurants because not everybody can get 4 or 5*. The decor is great, the atmosphere is so-so and the food was good but not great.   BTW: Large tasting menu, small testing menu, one glass of wine and two drinks $350.00 includes tip. Just for your info.

JonlkHMeerqgQpq_1V6xIg.text: Had the most amazing dinner at Sage last night!  Everyone from the hostess to the wait staff to the sommelier were fabulous!  By far one of the best meals we've had all week.  Sage never disappoints and we'll be sure to return!

LbOka-PSGMsUjMkvJLUeKw.text: I thought she was a very good restaurant. The vibe and mood when you walked in was cool and elegant. The food was good but expensive. ahQvX1HJ9XRYRKV9gmg1FA.text: I wanted to have a nice and quaint yet fancy dinner for Christmas so I booked this restaurant.   I like the fact that they didn't abolished their regaled ala carte menu and just serve the xmas set menu for the occasion. So we ordered the beef tartare to share and each have a main. Couldn't even fit desserts in even thou I was soooooo tempted by the 6 layered choc cake because the serving size was good.   Wagyu beef tartare was freaking amazing that came with buttered, crispy warm bread. And when combined with the silky yolk in a mouthful. It was freaking amazing.   My friend had the crispy confit duck and I had the smoked black cod. Duck was done to perfection and the cod was fresh, silky and smooth. Both had wonderful flavors   The service was fantastic as well. We had an amazing server that the origin of our champagne and how and why it taste the way it is. And we were really well taken care of in the drinks department. Even though we had to wait for quite some time at the bar, the server was so apologetic and acknowledged that we have been waiting and will bring us to our table as soon as thu can.   What can I say.. I will definitely come back to sage when I visit Vegas again.

gb-BrjqIfVBoZSyhO3pdZg.text: Quality New American Fine Dining Experience with Exceptional Service. Prior to arriving in Vegas, my friends decided we wanted to do one fancy, fine dining dinner where we could get all dressed up and act all "BOUGIE". We called in reservations earlier in the week and booked a 7:30 dinner time no problem on a Saturday. After we all gathered, albeit a little after 7:30 cause part of our party caught a hot streak at the tables, the staff was gracious enough to honor and hold our reservation. We were seated in the back of the restaurant which was nice since it seemed more quiet yet we were not neglected as each section had a maitre'd like supervisor making sure quality service was being delivered at all times. After looking over the menu, my friend who made the reservation asked about the Chef's Tasting menu and our waiter grabbed the menus for us. When we made a decision on which fine dining establishment to fancy, we saw this delicious 4 course tasting menu for $79 dollars with an optional $39 wine/beer pairing. The majority of us ordered the tasting menu and heres a snap shot of the magic I ate that night: Amuse Bouche: yelp.com/biz_photos/f9sU... 1st Course, wagyu beef tartare: yelp.com/biz_photos/f9sU... 2nd Course, Bacon wrapped rabbit served over mushroom ravioli: yelp.com/biz_photos/f9sU... 3rd Course, braised veal short rib: yelp.com/biz_photos/f9sU... 4th Course, Apple Caramel Nomage: yelp.com/biz_photos/f9sU... Some of the finest tasting food I've come across so far. Our waiter was phenomenal, very professional yet kept us laughing all night long. The wait staff that served our food knew exactly who ordered what and gave very detailed explanations of the food and how it was prepared. My friends who had the wine pairing absolutely loved it and my friend who didn't order the tasting menu said her meal was superb as well.. Overall a truly fantastic dining experience. I would highly recommend this place if you are looking for a fine dining establishment with out paying the outrageous prices that some establishments have.

0U9gdGEUAi2CFM62nuU1XA.text: The overall experience was beautiful. The wait staff were adorable. I ordered an old fashioned to start. There was a palate cleanser of a soup that I can't recall the taste. Had a small sliver of fried onion on the top. It was delicious. I did the 2-course meal. I ordered the foie gras brulee. That was to die for. Very creamy and rich. Notes of strawberries and of course foie gras and melted/hardened sugar.  Then I had the braised veal cheeks. I ordered a red wine from the specialist. mourchon cotes du rhone. Asked her to pair it with the cheeks. And it was excellent. Of course it was my birthday and I ordered the chocolate torte that had notes of blackberries. The staff brought it out with a lit candle and happy birthday written on the plate ever so delicately. Overall, great experience. Especially for my first time.

Tq2qbOFr7-zMtjWyNWCpIg.text: We had dinner our last night in town at Sage. The scallop appetizer was the best scallop dish we have ever had! I had the short rib and the arugula salad.  Just wonderful. The server was amazing and so was the bartender. We ate at every other restaurant in the Aria and this one was by far the best.

lhTvoilXXgshahJzeZIc1A.text: Food that looks like food!  New American at its very best.  In the star-studded Michelin world filled with innovative cuisine, molecular gastronomy, and modernist techniques, ie, "is that a pebble on my plate or can I eat it".  Sometimes, it is refreshing to enjoy great food while being able to identify every ingredient on the plate.  This is Sage.  Incredibly well sourced, seasonal, fresh ingredients, each showing their own flavors blend harmoniously in a dish to elevate the primary protein.  The philosophy is clear in the amazing kushi oyster.  A tiny, uber fresh oyster with its subtle cucumber taste is enhanced by the tiny scoop of piquillo pepper and tobasco sorbet.  A tequila mignonette blends with its natural liquor and makes the perfect briny shot.  Seafood dishes skillfully combine land based ingredients to tease out the best flavors.  The oceanic sweetness of perfectly seared and cooked day boat scallops is brought to life by earthy trumpet mushrooms and meaty oxtail.  The caramel reduction creates an unexpected harmony.  The perfectly roasted turbot's sweetness is brought forth by the earthy porcini mushrooms and contrasts nicely with the caramelized onions.  A vegetal cauliflower emulsion makes the flaky fish seem voluptuous on the tongue.  On the other hand, beef, is treated simply, allowing it to be the star and accompanied by well chosen side garnishes.  The aged USDA prime rib cap is exceptional.  A very tender, flavorful cut of beef, simply grilled, sliced and allowed to speak for itself with nothing more than a garnish of root veg.    Deserts are a must for their very well controlled sweetness, or even tartness.  The raspberry soda (Greek yogurt sherbet, basil pearls, and raspberry marshmallow, tart, fresh explosion of raspberry flavor with a clean, herbaceous finish.  Be sure to close with absinthe.  Outstanding selection with the classic service (sugar cube dissolved slowly by drops of chilled water).  Herbaceous digestives whose complexity goes on and on.  Selections from both the US and around Europe.  Outstanding and informative "flavor map" so you know what to expect.  Polished and professional service.  Outstanding wine list.  The only flaw, if there is a major convention at Aria or if the hotel is sold, they do not manage seating times well.  This is the only top tier restaurant in the MGM chain that I have had to wait an hour past my reservation and still not be seated.  A replacement reservation the following evening went smoothly and the restaurant redeemed itself, delivering an outstanding experience.  Excellent.

1SYRyiDlcTFFC4JyZEUdlw.text: The ambiance is exceptional.  Unfortunately, everything else falls short. Our group of four arrived to the restaurant 20 minutes early. The restaurant made our group wait until our formal reservation time - but when we entered, the restaurant was half empty, and it never came close to filling up. It was perplexing and unnecessarily high handed. The absinthe cart looked very interesting - but the rest of the drink menu seemed unexceptional. A friend seemed to really enjoy the scallops, but my impression from the rest of the group was that the food was just adequate. I did not feel that my meal came close to expectations - certainly was not worth the price. The service, also, was mediocre.   My impression was, if you wanted to feel more important than you probably are, you should come to Sage.  There really are dozens of places I could think of I'd go back to or want to try in Vegas before I would consider giving Sage another try.

A-AfoOoEjsEfVnS-1mxGBw.text: 1st waitress took a while to come by, older masculine type women, sorry I forgot her name...we has the egg appetizer-YUCKY, aime kinda pork pudding-YUCKY TOO, wasnt fresh, I has the black sea Bass-YUCKY as well, we had eaten at CATCH, next door and the food was AMAZING and the service was EXCELLENT too, so we gave Sage a shot, absolutely horrible and service was bad too, SAVE YOUR MONEY AND GO TO CATCH INSTEAD

ptEW6r-lg6HWkgY6kv3ziA.text: This time around Sage was good but not great.  Service was slow and waiter had no idea what the best dishes were and what went into each.  Might have been new but in this case didn't seem trained.  Sommelier was great and recommended a great wine as well as cocktail.    For the meal, the scallops were great as usual.  Mackerel was a fantastic cut of fish but basic on the top end.  Some nice dipping sauces to give it a different feel, but the cut itself was very fishy in flavor.  The sea bass, on the other hand, was a must try and a fantastic order.  Fishy but with a nice char.  Some good sauces as well; seems like accompanied sauces are what Sage is notorious for.  For appetizers, the egg dip was fine, but really was just a nicely poached egg with truffle, and that's it.  French bread for dipping, but the complimentary bread was better.  We also tried the foie gras creme brulee.  Very interesting dish, especially considering it was an appetizer, but unusual to say the least.  Custard and foie gras with seasonal strawberries.  The foie gras was noticeable and really leaves a mark for the meal.  This is a must order even if you don't like fie gras just for its unusual texture and taste.  The dessert - the foie gras chocolate bar - was a pass.  Foie gras unnoticeable on this dish, especially as compared to the creme brulee.  More of a caramel chocolate bar with popcorn on top.  Nice looking dish in all, but definitely not worth the $20 price tag.  Foie gras taste was almost non-existent; just your typical candy bar.  Sage is a top notch restaurant for sure.  Prices are high but so is quality of preparation and cuts.  I would easily come back here but stick to the specialties and hope you catch the wait staff on a good day.

Z5fngyX0D7HY2gtz7iDYxA.text: I'm usually not impressed and leave hungry from all $$$$ restaurants, especially in Vegas where everything is unnecessarily expensive and subpar compared to whatever their celebrity chef is famous originally for.   Sage is by the celebrity chef who created Green Zebra in Chicago. The venue is beautiful, the cocktails artfully crafted, the food delicious. The service was subpar for a restaurant of this caliber, and did leave a bad taste in my mouth given how much we shelled out for dinner.   HOWEVER, I would recommend the following and will definitely be back: * Scallops - 5 stars: These scallops were incredibly fresh and delicious, meaty, and flavorful! They were complemented perfectly with super rich, tender short ribs stir fried with mushrooms. Highly recommend but not filling as an entree because it probably comes with 2.5 giant scallops. * Foie Gras Brulee - 5 stars: OMG soooo incredibly good. Warning: very rich. Crunchy on top, rich smooth foie mousse, served with toasted brioche yum. MUST ORDER. * Veal Cheeks - 5 stars: Tender with a thick sauce melt in your mouth decadent. Prepared with a mexican style flavor and really good.  * Iberico Pork - 5 stars: So delicious and a Yelp favorite. I couldn't decide between the veal and iberico so split both with a friend. The Iberico isn't as tender as the veal but you can't compare because it's a different cut of meat and I preferred the flavor and preparation. It was some of the most tender and marbled pork I've had and would definitely order this in the future. * Bread - Not the best bread I've had but good, and I loved the butter and flakes of salt.  SKIP: * Eggs - 3 stars: I LOVE eggs, but this was a frothy egg soup and was too watery. Did not enjoy.  Service in the restaurant (bar service was great) left something to be desired. The food was delicious though and this is probably the first upscale restaurant on the strip I have really been excited about in Vegas in years! If you're willing to spend on good food I would highly recommend Sage.

r7QkcBB8tctszUE1bjcDZQ.text: Stellar, stellar experience. I hate seeing recent reviews that say service is lacking, because I had what was probably the most engaging wait staff experience of any restaurant I've visited, anywhere.  It was 4 of us, feeding on each other's stupid jokes - not to say we were obnoxious or anything, but just...obviously joking and and laughing, in a good mood. The waiter was able to read the table, jump in to our jokes without forcing it, and...for lack of a better term, connect with us easily. Never felt faked, it was just really personal and nice. Didn't hurt that he was very witty - some pretty clever jabs. Plus he was extremely helpful in recommending food and drink. So, massive, massive points for the wait staff.  The table went for the tasting menu, and we were not disappointed. Added bonus - guest chef for the weekend was Graham Elliott, whose restaurant in Chicago I really enjoyed a few years back (maybe 9 or 10 at this point).  Amuse bouche was an oyster with a lot of little accompaniments (I specifically remember creme fraiche, thank you South park) that was very mild, very tasty. I don't crave oysters, but this was quite good, and even a diner who wasn't a seafood person said it was very good.  Then a salad of baby arugula with burrata, marcona almonds, and a nice piece of honeycomb. This was great. By themselves, the arugula was a little bitter/salty, the honeycomb overly sweet, but combined together and with the mild, creamy cheese and the crunch of the almonds, we all cleaned our plates.  Duck confit ravioli was excellent, in a sort of spicy mild mushroom broth and tiny cubes of beet. The beet was quite mild, but the duck was extremely flavorful and rich, with the pasta perfectly cooked. Again, table agreed, we could have eaten a lot more of these. I particularly loved the spicy broth with the ravioli, and most of us all but drank anything left after the ravioli were gone.  Next scallops with chorizo and stewed peppers. The scallops (two nice sized ones) were cooked just right for me, a little rare in the middle, but not too much, with a nice sear and good flavor. A little grit, not excessive. None of the flavors here were over the top - again, a friend who would never normally order seafood was glad to have tried this, even if it wasn't up his alley, so they appealed pretty universally.  And oh man, the wagyu ribeye cap. So rich and flavorful, perfectly cooked between rare and medium rare. The truffle listed on the menu wasn't overpowering (I think it's frequently overused and covers up other flavors). Again a pretty nice sized helping, I wish this went on and on. I was excited to see ribeye cap on the menu and I was well rewarded.  And then dessert, undersold as a "banana split". Delicious bruleed banana, vanilla gelato, plus candied hazelnuts that I would have eaten 10 pounds of, and chocolate sauce. Plus I feel like a really rich, maybe liquor mascerated cherry and some strong cherry sauce, perhaps leaking from the cherry. Simple thing, but really excellently executed.  Now we're stuffed and it's time for the absinthe course. Our excellent waiter takes his time, explains the whole thing to us, passes around bottles from his dedicated absinthe cart for us to smell and compare, then even comps us one more item than we ordered so we could try more kinds and the different preparations (one of which involved huffing the vapors from flamed absinthe? Awesome!)  Just an exceptional experience across the board. Every course was great, service was fantastic. The meal was expensive, but no one felt like it wasn't worth it. If I have to recommend a great experience to someone based on this and my last visit, Sage is way up there for Las Vegas when you're looking for something a little creative but not overdone.  And I just realized that this was my 1000th review, and I didn't even plan it that way - glad it was something good!

24wsehezoHm5sasYroEI-g.text: Had the chef tasting menu. I was happy with my meal... but not mind blown. I really enjoyed the honey and burrata on my arugula salad... great combination of taste. I was not wowed by the duck confit ravioli nor the scallops. But i really enjoyed Wagyu rib eye and dessert: banana split. Carmalized bananas with pretzels on the bottom was perfection!   But absolute favorite was the oysters. Sooooooo gooooood! And friendly service as well.

NvkWwMm34Yu5Huc6O_qwBw.text: Hate the music they played. Nice classy place to eat but the jazz blues music was loud and not conducive to fine dining. I prefer  soft, relaxing, soothing jazz music. Also 45 minute wait to serve our order. Unbelievable! And the worst, the food was lukewarm. I hate to complain about it because they might fix the problem but spit on my food when they return it to me.  Will definitely not come back  and will discourage friends not to go there. I don't care paying expensive stuff but should be worth it. Cheesecake factory or Yardhouse was even better.

noGSedj63Y8CpgJnaj-ErQ.text: We love Sage! Sage is a beautiful restaurant with excellent service and delicious food!  Management here is very professional and every time we've dined at Sage we've had amazing service.  The steak tartar, fish dishes, lobster rissotto,  chicken,  desserts, and bread are all favorites of ours.  I highly recommend choosing Sage for your next fine dining meal in Las Vegas!

PpPVRTJeuGZn5SfRsweHXQ.text: I tried the tasting menu and it was worth the $$$$.  Wagu steak. Scallops and dessert. I also had the absynthe.  You must try it.  the waiter was a little slow and condescending but it was fine, I was hammered on absynthe and purple dragon who cares.

q8wTRkhLmg_kyUU9vdXjYQ.text: Absolutely magnificent. I convinced our little Vegas posse that we should treat ourselves to dinner here - we went all-in with the tasting menu and the wine pairings and it was magnificent in every way.  The service was flawless, the food was from a chef at the top of his game and the wine was tremendous.   We made the reservations about two months beforehand for a Satruday night, and we had a round-top in the middle of the restaurant.  If you are even considering a blow-out meal on your Vegas trip come here !

vfZWFauMd3rVQN6tWMldxQ.text: Great service and a nice ambiance.  I think in terms of fine dining in vegas, this place is probably the best bang for the buck.  By no means is it cheap, but you can easily spend much more at other top restaurants in Vegas for food that is of similar quality.  I'd definitely give this place a try out if you are looking to splurge on a dinner in vegas.

l6dea5A9X6LPISkuguK5Jw.text: I have no words to describe how much we enjoyed the service and food at Sage like I said I have no words simply amazing starting from the staff to the food no regrets......

ZpHFtzKnZzk9xBNOfv1rwQ.text: It's really tough to not give most of the strip restaurants in Las Vegas 5 stars. They really know what they're doing and it shows.  The food is great, the drinks are great, the service is great. I went once, returned a week later and they remembered my name and some of my preferences. That's service.  It's a bit pricey, but if you're dining in nice places at the Aria, you can't expect not to pay through the nose. Worth every penny.

jetaorRFx1j-eY1saaXp5Q.text: We did the four course meal option Sage offers for $89 a person, and it not only was one of the best meals I've had in Vegas, it was one of the top two meals I've ever eaten. Everything was prepared excellently, the service was impeccable and the atmosphere was perfect. The only meal that tops this was my personally cooked omikase from James Beard award winner Nobuo in Scottsdale. That should tell you how great this meal was. Highly, highly recommend.

IWoVopXs71RwS9dgUnWPRw.text: I was so excited to try Sage after one of my best friends raved about it!  I would have given it 5 stars if they hadn't basically kicked us out at 11pm.  They took our reservation for 3 at 10pm, but that's ok. The scallops more than made up for it!  WOW!    I had a glass of wine, but my friend had the ginger beer drink and it was AMAZING!  Very impressive!  Even came in a copper mug. The restaurant is very beautiful and very simple.  We had two waiters- one was very knowledgeable and gave excellent recommendations, and the other was delightfully sarcastic:) Overall, we had a very enjoyable experience.

h14pmA68oBw6Fgf723dRYA.text: We've been having trouble going to places that are fine dining lately.  We had a couple of bad experiences where the service and food just did not match our expectations.  This was not the case here.  We ordered a la carte, a lot of food and were completely happy.  Sweetbreads - always my favorite, and these were cooked perfectly. Octopus - Big pieces of braised octopus that were charred, lovely. Charcuterie plate - pickled cauliflower?  Yes please!  beautiful meat selection. Beef Tartare - The texture of this egg was so perfect and I loved the saltiness of the capers mixed in, served with grilled bread, the chocolate shouldn't scare you off, you can't taste it really, it just adds a nice crunch to the plate. Beef Belly - not sure how they cook this one, but the texture was just phenomenal.  Still super moist but falling apart.  I rarely eat beef entrees but this one was great. We finished off with oysters which were served with a tobasco sorbet.  I don't love big briny oysters, but these were small and sweet and were just wonderful.  We had an Intermezzo of white chocolate filled with a meyer lemon soup and some celery.  Honestly.  I don't think words can describe what an amazing 2 bites that was.  Desserts were phenomenal as well, My favorite was probably the chocolate with hazelnut.  But The apple strussel with truffle (that's right the mushroom not the chocolate) ice cream was phenomenal as well.    The service was also great, very friendly and warm.  We sat at the bar and had a lovely time.  I highly recommend.

JFtePHUJo_rBeq-S0K8IAA.text: Great food, great drinks, quiet romantic place.  Food was exceptional...poached egg appetizer was a top ten of all time...scallops we're amazing.  Prices were acceptable and waitstaff was knowledgable and prompt. Would return for sure

h8HcM6YAxka83Pj-QhkmZA.text: Sage is a restaurant where you can be casual in an extremely elegant envrionment....every table is a good table...none are too close together so you feel private even in a large room and service is meant to pamper.   The food is straight forward without being the least bit oridinary...a poached orgainic egg doesn't sound new or anything special or typical fine dining fare...but put it on top of a delicate slightly smokey potato foam accented with shaved black truffle and a pine nut espuma..ART!  To take a humble food and elevate it to a very special place is not easy.  Sage does this.  Expect that you will have a feast for all senses.    And when you are asked to see the Absinthe cart at the end of you meal complete with at least nine international and domestic varieties...ACCEPT...it is presented and prepared traditionally or with a Vegas twist...on fire if you dare. DARE...it's amazing. It gives you an energetic buzz and you feel less full...a True digestif!...the whole point right? The menu is eclectic and yet varied and fanciful...  The chef also offers a 6-course tasting menu that isn't printed but can be available if everyone at the table is the mood to participate and have an extra special dining experience.  It can even be vegetarian or vegan and accommodate taste restrictions...and for the money...have a wine or artisnal beer paring with it.  STUPENDOUS....$120 for the food and $60 for the  beverage pairing! Great bar and outrageous cocktails.

PpcWecr65FY1Vdx0QGJM-A.text: One of the best meals I ever had.  Everything was excellent, the staff, food and atmosphere.  All this in the glamorous Aria Hotel.  The meal was worth every cent and more!

PUeUL1-g-m6el8N-uyZlRQ.text: You ever walk into a bar for the first time and say to yourself, " Oh, I'll be back here again...maybe tomorrow night..." ?   That.  And that was before we even ate the food.  Our charming and expert bartender Aaron was fun to watch, solicitous about our likes and dislikes, cocksure in his mixing and his opinions, and who skilfully entertained us while also leaving us to our conversation.  The modified classic cocktail menu was fun to peruse and the Last Word cocktail I had was gorgeous, complex and sent me to dinner with a lovely little hum in my head....  I read about the foie gras Creme brulee and it seemed like a must-have, but I had hesitations.  I don't like whimsical food, nor do I like food that tries to emulate something opposite (for instance, a dessert out of meat.)   Aaron strongly recommended it though,  as did our server James (more on him later).  What the hell, I was game....  Rather than rhapsodize about it here, read the other poetic odes contained in these reviews, and they are accurate.  I would like to add though that it is NOT whimsical food.  It is not a play on dessert.  It is an appropriate and accurate expression of the aspects that make foie gras beautiful, the texture and delicate flavor and the mouth feel.  Yum.  Aaron told me to order one to share  but I ate more than my half, and wanted more.   My girlfriend and I weren't hungry enough to order the tasting menu, so we picked two appetizers and split an entree.  I will return another time for the tasting menu, properly hungry.    The poached egg was a great example of what a skilled chef can do with a few perfect ingredients.  Shellfish and sweetbreads were not going to pass the lips of my dinner mate, so James, our attentive, funny server steered us to the Iberico pork loin which was perfectly prepared.  The amuse bouche was tar tare (bright and delicate) and the chef sent out a beautiful tiny hot chocolate with coconut to end our meal.   We skipped dessert and went back to Aaron, guessing correctly that asking him to make us something alcoholic and dessert-y would be a task he was up to...he didn't tell us a name for it, but it was chocolate, cold, foamy and perfect.  I haven't mentioned the bread, the wine, the sommelier, the beautiful decor in the dining room that is simultaneously hip and comfortable, the  pace at which the food came to the table, etc., all very good.   I left Sage wanting more.  (And yes, I came back the next night for more.)

0s-BvkTfqCwKolf6vqBROw.text: Fixed menu was absolute delish, but the wait time between courses was painfully slow.

ORgQGrBkxriq78MI4PYHTA.text: Sage is a great restaurant! I can't believe I didn't come here sooner. I wish I had discovered Sage MUCH MUCH MUCH earlier since I have been staying at the Aria since they opened. Decided to try some new restaurants during our latest trip to Vegas in June. Saw that Sage had great reviews (for good reasons) and it's right in the hotel. Came here on a Monday without reservations (closed Sundays), greeted by a hostess and seated promptly. I got to seat on the couch, which reminded me of Spruce. We opted for menu items rather than a tasting as we were on a bit of a time crunch. Complimentary Amuse-Bouche: Cherry tomato with avocado mousse. 4 stars. Light and refreshing. yelp.com/biz_photos/f9sU... We chose the bacon bread over the sourdough. It was loaded with bacon, I am not a fan of bacon but this was really good. The lavender infused butter and the sea salt went very well with the bread. 3.5 stars yelp.com/biz_photos/f9sU... Ordered the signature foie gras custard 'brulee'. Sounded 'interesting' and I didn't have any idea how the flavors will play out, but the sweetness of the brioche mixed with the foie gras flan was absolutely delicious! Creamy and a little sweet. Loved it, 5 stars! They brought us some additional brioche for the custard as well. It can get a little heavy so you can't eat too much of it. Perfect for sharing. yelp.com/biz_photos/f9sU... I forgot the name of the drink I ordered, but it was made with tea vodka, St. Germaine, rose water, and had a couple of pinenuts. Slightly bitter but great on the pallet, with a hint of sweetness. 4 stars yelp.com/biz_photos/f9sU... The seared bigeye tuna sashimi was not what I had expected. Bf ordered the dish and I didn't read the description. I wasn't crazy about the anchovies, and I don't like olives. The sauce is a bit pungent and overpowering with the strong taste of vinaigrette. The tuna itself was tender and soft. I would pass on this. 2.5-3 stars yelp.com/biz_photos/f9sU... Wagyu beef tartare - 4.5 stars. Beef was very tender, and well seasoned. The caper aioli and mustard seeds gave the meat a nice little touch of flavor. Shaved chocolate was interesting but blended well with the tartare. The bread I was not so crazy about, loved the brioche and bacon bread much more. yelp.com/biz_photos/f9sU... Potato-crusted arctic char - 5 stars! I am in love! The fish layered with thin strips of potato and the skin wraps the outside, the potato skin is crunchy and gives the fish a great texture that you cannot get from fish skin. Saffron cauliflowers and green grapes add great flavor and texture. I am craving for some more!! yelp.com/biz_photos/f9sU... Maine Day Boat Scallops - perfectly cooked. So tender and juicy! With the braised oxtail it gives it quite the punch. A great way for surf and turf. yelp.com/biz_photos/f9sU... We were too full and out of time for dessert, complimentary chocolate caramel soup was served. 4.5 stars. Yum, like a perfect hot chocolate. yelp.com/biz_photos/f9sU... What stood out besides the food was the impeccable service. You can tell that the servers actually care. Our server Jason had to leave during our meal due to change of shift, and he gave the best possible explanation I have ever heard in my entire dining life. And Robert was enchanting and funny, what a personality! He had a great introduction, and was very personable. Both were very attentive and they made my experience at Sage that much better. I will definitely be back next time I am in town, granted there are so many restaurants to choose from. Great food and great service, what restaurants and fine dining should be all about.

Mbfq8j_BYgAV4NB03fpepA.text: I would give it 4.5 stars if I could.  I would like to reserve 5 for places that make me lose my mind.  This isn't one of those, but it still was one of the better meals I've had in a very long time.  So, better than 4 stars... I'll give 'em the benefit of the doubt and inch it up to 5. (-:   Everything we had was both rich and fresh.  I had the fois grois brulee, which is one of their signatures. Very unique and super-tasty.  Had the scallops for an entree, which rocked my world. How they do seafood that fresh in the desert continues to confuse me.  The palette of flavors was hearty and earthy and a bit sweet - a very nice combo.  Service was flawless and attentive.  They need to change out some of their lightbulbs, as the dramatic lighting, despite being cool, was a bit sharp on the eye.  But, that's a very nitpicky complaint.  The fact that I bring that up as my only real complaint shows how good a place this is.  It was pricey (no surprise there) - but worth it for the experience and the tasty bites.    Highly recommended!

HgBJz-UXW19MSew1OjX1lQ.text: BEST KEPT SECRET. I'm so glad I came here before all the hype, because seriously, michelin star/top chef/celebrity chef type restaurants are a dime a dozen in vegas. Tucked in the Aria hotel, is this amazing restaurant. I knew it from the bread. When they offer you a biscuit, you take it, regardless of if you're going carb free or not. Had the signature tasting menu and everything was amazing. We also ordered the oysters which were SO fresh and delicious, but so expensive (this was in addition to the tasting menu since we orderd the foie gras supplement), they disappeared fast. The waygu beef tartare was very good, especially since we both aren't fans of raw beef generally. Dessert is usually my favorite but I didn't enjoy the olive oil ice cream too much, was weird for me. Overall a great experience.  All in all, everything was great, the service was not stuffy at all and they made it very welcoming, because let's face it, not everyone is a gazillionaire in Vegas and some of us normal people just want to eat good food too. Sage, I was weary to give you a high rating, because I don't want you to get too popular for me!!

iUQjtabdhdPFiryPYm4eQg.text: My meal I had here is in my top 5 meals I EVER had... yes, Gary Danko, Keiko's, French Laundry, Guy Savoy, and Joel Robuchon, someone has stepped in the arena and is a MAJOR player.    Service was a bit slow at the beginning and we were questioning if we made a mistake coming here, but then it got much better.   We had the signature menu $89/per person:  *Foie gras creme blulee:  Can you say nice and creamy like and a bit of sweetness like the combo of peanut butter and jelly.  Holy crap! *Bison takaki: First time I had bison and from what I was told by friends is that it is a bit gamey.  Nope, not this.  Tender and melted like butta in my mouth. *Heirloom tomato salad: It was a great follow up from the bison.  Light and tasty.  Sometimes people go overboard with the vinegar.  Not this.  Very smooth tasting. *Wagyu beef tartar: This is another Holy Crap moment.  I thought this dish was going to be too heavy.  Nope.  The slow poached egg on top with the toasted bread... DELISH! *Grilled Spanish octopus:  I rarely order octopus because 95% of most places over cook this.  Oh this place hit the mark!  Nice smokey flavor and has some "toothie-ness" but not chewy AT ALL. *Dayboat scallops, braised oxtail, caramel reduction:  I was totally surprised that you get two huge scallops!  The sauce was to die for.   *Iberico pork loin: Ok... that should say it all.  Anything that is Iberico pork is heavenly. *Beef belly: This was soooo tender and deep in flavor.  We jokingly said that all the dish was missing was white rice.  The waiter went next door to the other restaurant and got us a bowl.  Now that  is service! *Gianduja pave (olive oil ice cream):  I wanted to pick up the plate and lick the whole thing.    They had two different breads: sourdough roll and a bacon roll.  If you're from the Bay Area skip the sourdough.  Nothing compares or comes close to our local stuff.  The bacon roll was tasty.  The couple next to us ordered the funnel cake.  It was sooooo tiny and they said it didn't taste as good as the ones you get at the ballpark or county fairs... cause probably this was a healthy version LOL!  I will DEFINITELY come back here.  EVERY single dish was a major hit.  I can't say that about Joel R.  I  know there are 16 dishes for JR, but none of the dishes was a Holy Crap moment.  I can also say that I never had a Holy Crap moment at Gary Danko's either.  Wow.... I can't believe I said that!  Can't beat the price, quantity and quality of food for $89!

D3RKv3AR4pnrvvrTURINLg.text: The food, the service, oh my gawd it was THE BEST.   I came here with my friends after Jean Georges lost my dinner reservation and thank god for this place. I got their $79 Signature Tasting Menu and it was very satisfying, not to mention filling. What I got on the tasting menu was: First Course: Wagyu Beef Tartare Second Course: Glazed Pork Belly Third Course: Iberico Pork Loin Fourth Course (Dessert): Peach Praline   I would most definitely come back here the next time I'm in Vegas.

usKBLj8JzykCiKTVaOXYgw.text: First things first... Best salt I've ever tasted! They bring freshly baked rolls, herb butter, and salt to your table.  Get one of each roll if you can. So yummy! We ordered the poached egg worth truffles for an appetizer and they were not stingy on the truffles.  The egg was perfectly poached and the toast just melted in your mouth! For entrees we ordered the veal cheek and the gnocchi.  Both were great choices.  Although the gnocchi portion was not large I could not finish it because it was so rich (Not complaining). I can't remember what the dessert was called but it was a little chocolate disk.  Very yummy but not too heavy, which was perfect after our filling meal. Overall a wonderful experience. Wait staff was great and I felt we got a good value for the price. Definitely left happy and full!

NxvJrWV9pjLdnTKBvuW9cw.text: This is in my top 5 dining experiences in Las Vegas. My friend and I went here for just drinks and appetizers, and it felt like a full 5 course meal.   We started with 2 dirty martinis, and they were made to perfection. Then we ordered the WARM GOAT CHEESE CROSTINI with Candied Walnuts/Black Pepper Honey. Oh my. Heaven.  We then nibblled on SHISHITO PEPPERS with Spiced Lime Salt...very interesting. My friend liked them better than I did, but they were like edamame on steroids. A great "filler".  Next we tried the WAGYU BEEF TARTARE with Slow-Poached Egg Yolk and Crispy Chocolate. This was melt-in-your mouth good.   By this time we were seriously having food euphoria so we ordered another martini (again perfect) and wanted seconds of the Goat Cheese Crostini.   Our waiter - Jason Bond (for real) -  (who was awesome by the way) urged us to try to Oxtail crostini instead. Neither of us had ever had it, but we were feeling brave. Oh. My. It was like the tenderest pot roast you've ever had, with the flavor of onions and mom's Sunday dinner. Wow.   So...here's when I bit into a little piece of bone (literally). It was pretty gross since then I was thinking of tail. BUT, I didn't really care and I just politely pointed it out to the waiter. The manager came over, made a big fuss, apologized, etc. They handled it very well and took it off the bill.   Then the waiter brought us a complimentary dessert. It was a shot of mint infused chocolate...not too sweet, perfectly warm. It was seriously one of the best desserts I've ever had.   So, I still give this place 5 stars even though I ate a tailbone. That's how good it is. Going back at my first opportunity.

JSYe7KdJbQxiEVnWJFrrAg.text: One of the greatest bar/lounge experience I've ever had... We walked in for a drink, ended having some amazing starters and amazing crafted drinks and beers! Joe and Arron made our night at the bar!!! Thank you!!!

XN2cx4_LyUT45ZX22Qt15A.text: My family and I dined here for Christmas Eve dinner. We had the option of choosing the Christmas prix fixe menu (3 courses, $75) or Chef McClain's Signature prix fixe menu (4 courses, $85, $50 optional beer or wine pairing). We all chose to go with the Christmas menu, with each of us ordering different items from it.  After ordering, we were delivered bread. No bread basket. Each person was given a bacon bread roll (a round bread roll with bacon in it!) and a little sour dough baguette. Both were delicious, especially when topped with the butter and sea salt brought for the table.  Then we were brought an amuse bouche, which was delicious. It was pumpkin seeds, a piece of oven-dried tomato, some kind of tangy cheese I can't remember, and probably some other things - but so delicious. Just a very small bite served on a silver spoon.  For the first course, we had the Taylor Gold Pears & Shaved Brussels Sprouts, Foie Gras Custard Brulee, Wagyu Beef Tartare, and Vancouver Island Kusshi Oysters. All were delicious! The foie gras and tartare, though, were very rich - almost too rich to finish the entire serving.  For the main course, we had Dayboat Scallops, Braised Veal Cheeks, and Grilled American Skirt Steak. Again, all were delicious! Best scallops I've ever tasted. The braised veal cheeks had such a good flavor. And the skirt steak was nothing like what I usually think of when I think of skirt steak (which was a good thing).  For dessert, we had the Honeycrisp Apple Tart and Dark Chocolate & Espresso Mousse Cake. Both were great, but neither were "wow" desserts.  The cocktail, beer, and wine list was great. I especially appreciated the beer list. It was filled with the type of beers one would actually have with such a type of meal. Classy beers with tremendous flavor profiles that pair well with the food.  The service was pretty much outstanding. Only complaint is that despite the server asking what our plans were after / if we had any time constraints (we were promptly seated at 5:00pm and had tickets for a 7:00pm show), it was 6:25pm before we got our dessert course and 6:45pm before we got our check (after flagging him down). Ultimately, it all worked out, but we felt a little frazzled as we didn't want to be late for the show.  The decor and atmosphere is perfect. It's an amazing and enjoyable dining space. Understated purples and golds, just the right size tables, etc.

Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kobe skirt steak

aWVAZ7LE-JgwoMHG0AcI0A.text: Second stop on our continuing Aria foodie crawl, part two.  This is the best restaurant of the whole bunch I dare say.   Sage has an excellent selection of beer on tap and our bartender, Brad, let us try a few before settling on a drink.  They have the Dogfish Midas Touch on tap ($12), which is super yummy.  And they serve it in an actual Dogfish beer glass.  Classy!  My husband got a beer cocktail, which is called the European Union ($14).  Youngs Chocolate Stout, Lindermans Framboise Lambic, and Cardenal Mendoza Solera Gran Reserva brandy.  I thought this would be awful, but I tried some and it tastes terrific!  They have Sierra Nevada 30th Anniversary Ale on tap, which is a rare find indeed!  We did not try it because we have a bottle at home but after we try the bottle, we may need to come back and compare it on tap.  Check out my pic of the menu to see what else they have on tap.  For food, we tried the salumi which comes with pickled green beans ($9).  Very yummy.  We also had the poached egg ($7) which comes with bacon (yum!) and bread to dip.  Very good.  Finally we had the beef tartare ($9) which is topped with an egg perfectly cooked over medium and crispy chocolate flakes.  Sooo good, I could not stay away.  Portion sizes are reasonable.  Not too tiny, but not overwhelmingly big either.  Apparently you can only get the bar menu at the bar - and they have some really special items there so I suggest you check it out.  The bar only has seating at the bar.  There are two round tables in front of the bar but those are only for people waiting for a table.  Also, they serve beer in 64 oz growlers but our bartender did not recommend it.  First, it results in a messy pour and, second, the beer gets warm too fast.  Apparently, when the restaurant first opened they thought it would be a good idea to sell beer to go in the growlers.  But Aria put a kabash on that.  According to our bartender, it's all good to have people running around with big ass margaritas in glasses or plastic yards but not beer in growlers.  They serve the full menu at the bar as well, and we debated trying the famed foie gras creme brulee but we were getting full and had a few more restaurants to try that night.  Next time!  I highly recommend checking out the bar next time you are in Aria.  It's not very expensive as compared to the nearby Todd English PUB but is much nicer with much more interesting beer and food selections.

COl2WCm0Y9I_Xax1YWU1Hw.text: I'm not sure what's more impressive - the cooking in the dining room or the drinks at the bar. Regardless, Sage is both my favorite restaurant and favorite bar in Las Vegas. This was the case when I first visited in 2011 and is still the case in 2015.  With the food, my basic suggestion (or sage advice) is to order the dishes with the most unique combinations. Using ingredients that might seem odd together, chef Shawn McClain somehow makes them harmoniously come together.  For appetizers, the fork-soft grilled octopus with chorizo, spinach, and pickled red onions was a marvelous combination of ingredients. I liked it better when the octopus was heavily charred and daringly served on smoky mashed potatoes, but it was still a wonderfully executed dish. The foie gras custard was so sweet, it was on the verge of being a dessert, but the creamy richness was undeniably good.  For entrees, the scallop and braised oxtail was a gutsy surf and turf combination due to the pairing of gentle scallops with strong oxtail. Additional strong ingredients were used like wild mushrooms, rapini, and butter-laden salted caramel reduction, yet the scallop didn't get lost. Quite amazing. The nicely crusted pork loin dish was fun due to the small singlets of spaetzle and well matched asparagus, but was held back due to the bland poached artichoke and mismatched herbal pork sausage.  If the foie appetizer was like dessert, then it only makes sense to actually make a foie dessert. The foie mousse was coated in chocolate like a candy bar and topped with melding ingredients like candied popcorn, Bourbon caramel, and peanut butter ice cream.  The drinks are impressive in many different ways. They have an international selection of absinthe, infuse their own cocktail ingredients, make their own bitters, stock hard-to-find whiskeys, and offer liquor flights. One Bourbon flight had six different ages of Pappy Van Winkle. Granted, it came at a high price at $500 for half-ounce pours.  The style of the constantly changing cocktail menu is bold. The cocktails here can be strong, herbal, gritty, bitter, rounded, or classic, but never soft, watery, sugary, or fruity. They are cocktails for real connoisseurs.  The only problems I had with this place were music selection and the uncomfortable chairs with cramping arm rests.

MGTFW75-rhTTsBk7EjpwAQ.text: After looking at the menu, I was worried about coming here for a company dinner, but they have a vegan menu! I did the whole vegan chef's tasting menu, and it was absolutely fantastic. The roasted corn gazpacho was so out of this world, I could eat it by the bucket. The roasted eggplant was amazing, and I HATE eggplant!! The service was wonderful, and our waitress Virginia was awesome. I would highly recommend Sage.

_bptGhYBW8nY_OAEtnSdrQ.text: One of my favorite restaurants on the strip. Food is always been good and tasty. You can never go wrong with ordering any dish on the menu.  We got waygu beef tartare, foie gras brulee, veal cheeks, and braised short ribs. This place is amazing!

koUP6kLXluT6ySM0Emvmgg.text: My second time eating here. While I love the flavors and fusions of food that I'd never expect to go together, tonight the service was too lax. It was downright cold in the restaurant--I am rarely cold, so others much have been freezing, which exaggerated the lax service. I was in a hurry to eat and leave because of the discomfort. It was a $70 meal for one, and while delicious, the service and temperature both brought the experience down. Til tonight, this was my favorite Vegas restaurant.  Overall, delicious food in an upscale modern atmosphere. The short ribs are delicious and foie gras a nice mix of sweet and gamey.

o_EQ9I2RBX1iENdnPUfg1Q.text: This was the most refined and delicious fine dining experience we have ever had. The food was incredible, and the atmosphere was modern and romantic. Our favorite dishes for the 4 courses are (in order) the pear starter, the soft poached egg, scallops, and wagyu steak.

vDzZ6wlAafV3fj728mwqmQ.text: Vegas isn't a place I associate with the farm-to-table concept. It's a desert, after all--not too many guys in overalls riding tractors nearby. And sustainability doesn't seem top of mind to the typical Vegas visitor, whose tastes lean more towards door-sized slabs of steak.  But Aria goes for a refined take on farm-to-table, in a chic but surprisingly loud setting. The small menu favors protein, and features some personal favorites--sweetbreads, octopus, and rabbit among them. I went for the veal cheeks and they were amazing, succulent with a texture similar to short ribs but somehow weightier and richer, redolent in a black garlic glaze with trumpet mushrooms and a corn cake that seemed out of place. Also had the octopus, and found it to be good but unexceptional.  On the downside, the limited menu may not suit all diners. My companion was looking for smaller plates of vegetables or seafood and she had very few options, with some (like the scallops) taken out of consideration because meat featured prominently in the presentation. Our server was reasonably attentive but had an odd, standoffish demeanor. And the wine list, while it included some unusual and lesser known labels, was pretty skewed toward Napa cabs with a pretty hefty markup. Not unusual in LV, but you'd think they would have tried for something more out of the ordinary.  Overall, a mixed experience, but I'd come back just for the veal cheeks.

Ah2UicfE4sI28gMZdqpCBA.text: This was the last place i ate before going back home in the morning.  I gotta say it was one of the best meals i had on this trip.  You walk in to this place and its a low lit ambiance, with refined decor.  Yes this place is on the pricey side but it well worth it, because not only the food was stellar,  but the service was just as great if not better.    I had the tasting menu which consisted of Chilled maine lobster, Foie Gras Brulee, Sea scallops, Herb-crusted Lamb Saddle, 48 hr braised beef belly, and to finish a Green apple Mousse.   Everything was done with love and care.  You can really taste the love they put into preparing all the dishes.  The Beef belly so so tender, almost like butter melting in your mouth.  Lamb saddle was very flavorful, with there herb crust enhancing the lamb flavor rather than covering up with gamey flavor.  My favorite dish though was the Foie Gras Brulee...... OMG!!!!!! It was so rich and such a smooth texture.    If i died after that meal.... i would died a happy man.

Ws332lx8gevmP0nv4yDVYg.text: We went to Sage in October '14 for our "fancy" dinner. First bad sign, it took us nearly 30 minutes to get our drinks, I think we saw our server 4 times total during our 2+ hour dinner there. I ordered a brussel sprout starter which was excellent. Had to wait about 45 minutes between being finished with our appetizers and getting our entrees. I ordered the scallops for my entree. First bite, I noticed the chef/cook had not removed the side muscle, which should have caused me to ask for a new dish, but I never send food back. To my detriment, the dish made me violently ill, made 2 mad dashes to the bathroom to throw up, couldn't finish my meal or one $15 drink. I then just prayed that the check would come quickly so I could go back to the hotel room and hope not to die. After waiting way too long on the check, we had it split into 3 checks for the 5 of us, I signed and ended the night.   The next morning, we went to brunch and my visa was declined, because my fraud alert had been triggered (unrelated), but when I called my bank, they were reading off the charges and I had over $400 worth of charges from Sage. I pulled out my receipt from the night before and told my bank that I only authorized $140. Well, these charges stayed on my account for a week after my vacation. I called several different people and left messages with the Aria and Sage about the incorrect charges, but never received a phone call back. Turns out they charged my friends for their dishes and then charged me for mine and AGAIN for my friends' dishes. Just to add insult to injury, I suppose. I will never be going back to this restaurant, would rather stick to my consistent favorite, the Eiffel Tower Restaurant in the Paris.

pRfGostPC5kpQXePDDE_GQ.text: We were staying at the Mandarin Oriental and had a positive experience when we came to Sage for dinner on a Friday night. We made the mistake of coming back on Sunday night to have a cocktail at the bar. Aaron B. was our bartender and I can say that, without a doubt, he was one of the most unpleasant people I've encountered in the service industry. If this was a low-rent bar with cheap drinks, I'd forgive him. But...we paid top dollar for an enjoyable high-end experience and, after attempting to make polite chit-chat with him about how he was making our cocktails, he became oddly aggressive and insulting -- as if we were idiots questioning the work of a master. Absolutely ridiculous.  A few moments later, we also overheard him complaining loudly about a female customer who was "so f--ing stupid that he had to explain every item on the menu three times." Very classy indeed.   For our last night in Vegas, it left a bad taste in our mouths. We visit Vegas often, but we won't be going back to Sage. There are too many other places to spend our money -- and we've encountered many other bartenders who make comparable drinks and understand how to engage with their customers.

-czqFMu0-9d4KhFkcaf3Rg.text: Beautiful restaurant located in the Aria hotel. The service was outstanding. The food was inventive and delicious.  We absolutely plan on going again on our next Vegas trip.

0VA90Ohn5x8DrL7WRU9O7g.text: This rating is based solely on drinks and the live entertainment. I ordered the bubbles which was delicious and very refreshing. Followed my champagne with the blueberry habanero. The blueberry habanero had the perfect amount of kick and made for the perfect dessert if you like sweet and spicy. Also tried the Old Fashion, which was by far the best old fashion I've ever had. The drinks were great but the live music was my favorite part of the experience. The singer had an incredible voice and played a range of music. Overall great spot for a relaxing after dinner drink.

ltSV6XFjGwSEO1Dhfj7XkQ.text: Amazing!    We got lucky, it was the night that Shawn McClain, executive chef was actually cooking.   We were a party of 6 and we all have the premium chef's signature menu for $150.    The waitress warned us that it would be a 2 hour dining experience.    In actuality, between the wine and great company, we were there for 4 hours.  The food looks like something out a magazine, smells great, and tastes refreshing with every bite.   We started out with complimentary oyster to wash our palate, I swear it smells like the ocean, something a little mermaid would enjoy.   Then so many dishes after that, I don't recalled anymore.   My favorite was the pan seared scallops, it was the right texture, best tasting scallops I ever had.  Definitely will be back whenever we go back to Vegas.

FWhvYvytpJqqto3LH1xeow.text: I know this is super late! But I went for thanksgivings an I was so happy they was open for me. I love the food an services. Even know that they're a Expensive place to eat, it's Worth it. Everyone should check the Sage out!

5O9W5j1Rjl0Ev3iXHepaPQ.text: Awesome meal -- one of the better ones I've had in Vegas. The dishes were stunning in presentation, inventive, and well executed. If you appreciate food, Sage is one of those splurges that is worth experiencing. My wife and I opted for the signature tasting menu, which seemed like the popular choice.   Decor/atmosphere - modern and sophisticated, dark and romantic yet without being too dark without being able to see anyone or any food. We sat in a table off to the side, and it was private and comfortable. I loved how the light shined on the table, as if to present our dishes like artwork.   Kind of random, but the background music they played reminded me of that fancy restaurant "Claw" the movie Date Night, where Steve Carrell and Tina Fey stole someone's reservation and all hell breaks loose for the rest of the night.  Anyway, on to the food. My wife and I ordered separate dishes for each course, just so we could sample as much food as possible.  - Amuse bouche: cauliflower gazpacho, in mini shot glass. It was cool and refreshing with subtle flavors -- a nice way to start things off and initiate the taste buds.  - 1st course: market oysters and the foie gras brulee. The oysters tasted so clean, so fresh, and I loved the little kick from the tabasco sorbet on top. The much talked about foie gras brulee did not disappoint -- it was rich, creamy, and super decadent. An original dish for sure, and while I enjoyed it, I don't see myself ordering this again.  - 2nd course: grilled spanish octopus and maine dayboat scallops. The octopus was unbelievably tender, and practically melted in my mouth. I wish there was a bit more of that grilled and smoky flavor for that added dimension, but just nitpicking at this point. The scallops were perfectly cooked, and I enjoyed the tiny bits of braised oxtail and mushrooms. I wanted more of that oxtail.  - 3rd course: 48 hour beef belly. My wife substituted for a pesto-like pasta dish, and while it was good, the only thing I can remember is my beef belly dish. This was my favorite of the night. Just imagine a beef version of a pork belly, but with even more flavor. There was a subtle hint of smoke, yet a bit of sweetness throughout the meat. I didn't really care for the peaches.  - 4th course: gianduja pave and pistachio tart. The pave was absolutely a stunning piece of edible artwork. Every component was so detailed and intricate that I felt bad wrecking it with my spoon. It was fun to eat, and the olive oil ice cream was a nice contrast with all the crunchy textures from the hazelnut crunch. The pistachio tart was also spectacular in presentation. It was good, but definitely not as memorable as the pave.  Overall, an excellent dinner. I was a bit disappointed that they didn't acknowledge our anniversary when I put it down as a reservation note, but hey minor details. Service was easy going, efficient, and on top of things. Our waiter had a flair for the dramatic, if you know what I mean, and sort of reminded me of Chef Art Smith in voice and demeanor (not looks). I'm glad to have dined at Sage, and hope to again in the near future.

3i5zOFnxI_W63dZPrrGAag.text: Friday night, last minute birthday dinner reservation for a group of 9?  In San Francisco, that would be a near impossible task to accomplish, but Sage was happy to accommodate us! #winning  To start: We were briefly introduced to the bar before getting seated.  After ordering a round of waters (too hungry to consume alcohol!) and getting acquainted with the menu, our dining experience began with a selection of sourdough bread and bacon bread with herb butter and sea salt.  I love bread and I simply couldn't get enough of these.  Although the bacon bread was a little on the oily side for me and the sourdough was a less sour than the SF variety, I had few complaints once I paired everything with the herb butter and salt.  The server even came around for a second time to offer additional rolls right before our food arrived!  +1 star for sure.  Next, we received a complementary amuse-bouche and that was an absolute delight.  The server was soft spoken when introducing the appetizer, however, so I cannot recall exactly what we had. The flavors were subtle and worked well with the cream and sweet fruits.   Main courses: Chef Shawn McClain's masterful menu includes a number of rich, indulgent, high value items.  Think oysters, sweetbreads, steaks, truffles, scallops, bone marrow...if any of these items make your mouth water, head on over.  Unfortunately, if you're vegetarian, the selection is far less accessible, although items can be modified (and prices adjusted) to accommodate dietary needs.  It was difficult to settle on just one dish, but I could never resist a good duck dish. :)  I ordered the duck breast with persimmon puree, spiced rillette, and roasted cauliflower.  The duck is sourced from Grimaud farms, and the meat is noticeably leaner than other duck varieties that I've had.  i appreciated the slightly crispy skin and the sweet-salty contrast of the persimmon-duck.  Excellent flavor, hearty portion, and beautifully prepared!  A few other notables: the gnocchi was the dish of the night (4 of us ordered it) and it stands out as a well-executed dish.  The braised wagyu short rib was solid too -- excellent job on the braising.   Overall - Everyone was pleased and satiated with the quality of their meal. - The food is rich and you will leave feeling full. - Aside from the soft spoken servers, service was pretty solid and the dining experience was efficient and well paced, allowing us to move on to our evening activities quickly. - Dessert options were primarily cream or ice cream based (and no birthday specials).  Again, too rich!

FAj85jFsSLfd_lmqwBgqOw.text: Sage was one of the best dining experiences i've had to date. A nice little trick we like to use, is to each order completely opposite tasting menus. We then share, and get to sample a massive amount of the offerings. The highlights on this occasion, being the outstanding Waygu Beef Tartare, and the Rabbit backstrap. Additionally, the desert featured a block of olive oil chocolate, surrounded by pomegranate seeds, and various insane magical elements(See pic!).   The wine selection can easily be described as Expansive, however, with the prices ratcheting up to over $10,000/bottle, it could easily be confused with Expensive. To be fair; you can find a bottle of red for a little as $50, if you try hard enough ; )  If you find yourself in Vegas, make a reservation at Sage. You will be glad that you did. It does not disappoint.

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Olive Oil Chocolate menagerie of magic.

B7lklvTMJvu6LD69FxZLJQ.text: You wouldn't expect Sage to be a farm-to-table dining concept, judging by its sleek modern decor and hip ambiance. High-quality and fresh ingredients are used to create unique dishes possessing a complexity of flavors.   Chef McClain's Signature Menu offers a well-rounded sampling of delicacies featured on their regular menu. My friend and I ordered from the same menu and tried each other's orders, because sharing is caring.  Wagyu Beef Tartare: I loved the richness of the beef. It tastes great when spread all over slices of toasted bread. The chocolate shavings were more decorative rather than adding to any of the beef's flavors.   Foie Gras Custard Brulee: Much more savory than I was expecting, but still good. Figs or another sweet fruit might've been better choices instead of the bitter kumquat.   Grilled Spanish Octopus: A mild and light dish compared to my Maine Day Boat Scallops. The octopus was perfect and tender -- what more could I ask for?  Maine Day Boat Scallops: Everything in my heavy boat of a plate melted in my mouth. The two plump scallops were perfectly cooked, as well as the braised oxtail and mushrooms.   Bacon-Wrapped Iberico Pork Loin: In this case, there's no such thing as too much pork. The braised pork belly was melt-in-your mouth delicious, but it wasn't the star of this dish. There's also sorts of rich flavors and textures in this dish that make it delectable. One thing I wasn't crazy for was poached pear flavored with anise and licorice -- just not a fan of the flavor combination.   Dark Chocolate Panna Cotta: The dessert overall was delicious, but I'll admit that I didn't like the red velvet sponge cake, mainly for its texture - I still devoured every . single . crumb.   Foie Gras Candy Bar:  The Foie Gras Candy Bar is what really attracted me to Sage. It's unlike any other dessert and foie gras dish that I've eaten. Essentially, it's like a luxurious Snicker's Bar with bourbon caramel, salt & pepper peanut butter cream, and chocolate crumbles and a dusting of gold...and it's pretty bomb.  Lychee Green Tea: Aromatic and flavorful.   To finally finish off  dinner, our server presented us with complementary hot chocolate with rosemary in "shot glasses," which was smooth and delightful.  The service was great. Staff was professional, personable, and attentive.   Conclusion: Dine here if you want to spoil yourself or someone else.

syb2G5e4ehWHieXwHX2bLA.text: Came here for my bday dinner and it was great. The place was really fancy and had a nice dark romantic feel to it.   I got the prefix menu that consist of Beef tartar, scallop with oxtail and mushroom, the 48 hour  beef belly and ended with the lemon cheesecake for like $89 dollars.   The beef tar was okay. It's kinda hard to have anything better than Craft's wagyu beef tartar so it was only okay. HOWEVER, I did really love their version of the crostini. There were like 3-4 pieces.  I also tried my brother's foie gras appetizer and that was spectacular. Also tried one of the oyster and wow was that really good(I'm not even an oyster fan but that oyster was amazing. (provided w/ pics)   The thing that really made me love this place was their EXCELLENT oxtail mushroom scallop. IT was SOOOO good. The aroma that came was excellent and wanted to make me drool. Came with 3-4 pieces of mushrooms and a piece of oxtail that actually looked liked a mushroom cause of the sauce. the sauce was excellent.Then of course the excellent and fresh scallop when you pair them all together is spectacular. I don't know how else to describe it but it was prob the best scallop I ever had.   48 hour beef belly: It was also really good. It's not the scallop AMAZING but it was still very good. Obviously when you braised it for 48 hours, it's soft and tender and is seasoned well. Obviously can't go wrong with the potato puree and  sides.   The only reason why I decided to give it a 4 is the lackluster finish of the lemon cheesecake. The deconstructed desserts that they have is more of a gimmick than tasting good imo. It didn't taste good at all imo. The other chocolate dessert panna cota was better though. I really recommend straying off from the lemon cheesecake.   With that said, if you're down for a fancy dinner in Vegas, Sage is a wonderful place to go to. The prefix menu is excellent and I would recommend it to anybody.

Which had food splattered onto it So then My wife and I moved ourselves to an empty table across the way and than a lady approach us and asked if everything was OK I said that that area is dirty so we moved ourselves here she says I'm sorry for that she had somebody clean it right away and then as I get my wonderful steak I noticed the wall to the right at that table also had some splash damage LOL that moment I didn't care for steak was good

CMI_4HYIQS_Qm-ied8HXGQ.text: We went in for tasting menu while we were attending a conference in town. I have done several tasting menu at amazing restaurants in New York and the overall experience here was below expectations.   Food: 3/5 Service: 3/5 Decor / Interior: 2.5/5  We also did wine pairing with the meal and through various courses, they poured wine while one of the members was not at the table. The description of wine and its pairing with the meal was also not as detailed as expected.

LAXnCkLTW-o4Hvve7mKN7A.text: This is supposed to be a high end restaurant and the dishes are supposed to be award winning. I agree with my yelp friend--it does not deliver the same food quality as a star restaurant.   I like that the restaurant is at least trendy and the dishes are more contemporary. Sadly they don't have much veggie dishes. Well, you can say that if we want veggie then we should find a vegetarian restaurant instead of coming here. But my point is they offer too little. Only 2 dishes of the whole menu don't contain meat or fish. This is not contemporary.  So we tried their egg with smashed potato. Very small dish with a poached egg on top of smashed potato. the taste was good, though very heavy. Thankful it is only a small dish. And surprisingly the bread coming with it looked like fully dipped in oil and fried. Not very healthy, nor pretty.   The mushroom dish was actually big to my standard. It was two eggs on top of a mixed mushroom bed. I like the mixed mushroom, but again it was way tooo salty, and oily. Didn't wanna eat it in the end.  My bf had their cod. I was very disappointed by the fish. I was not buttery as I expected, instead very smoky. I don't like it at all. But I end up liking the mussels on the side. Those are very fresh and tasty.  The wines here are bad, and expensive, I should say. That is the big down side. I mean the food tasted good in general, even though I'm pretty picky about it. But the wine was not tolerable. A class of pino noir costs $20 and is not good? No, thank you.

a5ItvJ68eFAjAG3UWUeDnw.text: Maybe it's my NYC taste buds, I wasn't dissapointed but I wasn't impressed either.   We both got the $89 4-course tasting menu. Waiter rec NOT to get wine pairing bc it's just something required by the casino and u get total of one glass for $44.   Amuse bouche complements of chef was beet and pomegranate, but too bad I ordered the same salad.  Guess I thought the one bite would be something more unique?  I started with the foie gras creme brulee which is delicious and taste just like you would imagine. Comes with a buttery bread to up the decadence. Husband got the oysters which he thought could be perfected.   I then got the grilled octopus which was tender and seasoned well.  Scallops were amazing!  For entree they let us sub duck breast which was delicious with duck breast and duck confit on lentils and creamy polenta.  Ricotta cheesecake and chocolate panna cotta with milk gelato both great desserts to finish.   Lastly we got rosemary scented hot white chocolate which was surprisingly yummy!
