C-Wekwz9TAMDRsLJvIRAUA.text: We happened to book Sage purely by chance as we usually like to finish off our Vegas trips with a lovely meal in cut but it was fully booked. This however was a blessing in disguise as Sage was simply fantastic and the whole experience was as good as any i've had worldwide. Myself and my wife made sure to order different items for each course so as we could sample each others and I can confirm that every dish was superb. The service was every bit as good as the food and our server (James M) was superb at his job. Highly recommend a visit!

aeekIZNMAzzVoEctkJh_8A.text: Charred octopus salad, Duck Confit....  all good what can say.....  except for the killer bacon bread.  A must to go to.

gcvhT8F0bETiif9b0v9UKQ.text: We went to Sage after positive reviews on Yelp.  After walking around the casino the first day and not seeing a lot of people we were a little put off that when we arrived on time for our reservation at 7:30 that they asked us to sit in the lounge.  We're going to order drinks so it's not that we're cheap but it always seems a bit like a hard sell when places do that.  But we followed orders and went into the lounge area.  Not packed by any means.  We found a couple of seats and waited.  And waited.  I know at least one bartender made eye contact with me but no one attempted to take a drink order (and they were moving about taking care of folks away from the bar) nor did we move--by now I was getting a nice pout going.  So we were probably there 10-15 mins with nothing happening as we accumulated chips on our shoulders.  The hostess then came up and asked us our names again and said OK our table was ready.  We were seated in a nice dining room with expansive ceilings and interesting art. When our server (James) appeared he asked how we were doing and I said with a genuine smile that we were trying to get over our "attitudes" and gave him a speed version of waiting, etc.  He apologized and said they were busy. A couple of minutes later he appeared with two glasses of champagne compliments of the house.  It was a nice gesture and immediately put us at ease.  The rest of the meal was very impressive as well and I was glad to eat it without being ticked off.  Very nice details on the food and the delivery (each course was explained as it was presented).  There was a tasting menu but we ordered from the regular menu--me lobster ravioli app and pork loin entree and my wife had a salad app and scallops entree.  Suffice to say the food was great--we eat out a lot at nice places and this one ranked up there with our Vegas experiences.  And yes the bacon rolls are amazing.  And the chocolate "soup" shot at the end of the dinner was wonderful as well. So a bumpy start turned into one of our better LV dining experiences.  2 apps, 2 entrees, 1 glass of pinot noir (plus our "free" champagne) and our chocolate shooters (on the house) and the bill came to $145 before tip. We would highly recommend.

Zx_r7cDqpkt6RuPDSYxi9A.text: I came here for my brother's engagement dinner, b/c our friend picked it out based on high yelp reviews. Sorry Yelp, you let us down a bit. On the plus side, the cocktail menu is huge, and the bartender is quite talented. I had a terrific Sazerac. On the other hand, the vibe is very snooty (wine and cocktail list are presented on an ipad, which is a cute gimmick, but kind of a pain to flip through), and the servers were as well. The food menu is quite limited and the cuisine was all heavy meat. My brother and I are vegetarian and they didn't have a single vegetarian entree. I muttered to him that, if the chef is good, he could whip something up, and the waitress overhead and chimed in, "he is very good". No he's not. The recommended appetizer was a slow poached egg with potato and shaved black truffle--sounded fantastic, but the flavors were way off. Somewhere between an ashtray and used cat litter. The special entree was no better and not filling either. The chef seems to heavily favor bitter, smokey, and highly acidic flavors and food was not balanced and totally lacking in seasoning. Coming from Northern California, where there are lots of great, great restaurants, it was painful to spend this much money on a meal that was so mediocre. I suppose if the idea of a $120 steak with bone marrow is your thing, then maybe this is your restaurant (although those who ordered it weren't raving about it). I am not familiar with the Vegas scene, but think that you should be able to get more creative, local, and flavorful cuisine for far less money than what we paid.

IN-3FOAqbeOyTsAoQazbyQ.text: This place in the new Aria hotel is nothing short of beautiful. Great place if you want to do it classy in Vegas. As the location should demand, the cocktails were impeccable. In fact, the bartender wasn't satisfied with the first one he made for my partner (we still thought it was pretty good), so he made her a new one. The wine list is similarly thoughtful. The sommelier suggested perfect pairings for our meals. The food itself is good, if not always up to the price point. I love salmon, but was disappointed that it was the only fish option on the menu at the time. It was certainly delicious, but I expected a little more creativity. Whatever's fresh, I suppose. My partner, on the other hand, absolutely loved the lamb. Definitely a good place for a special occasion, but not that friendly if you're not in the mood for meat.

Lyc0zkAbycmjw8ktt7cikQ.text: The food was outstanding, as were the drinks. The decor is simple, but cool. Service was top notch. Worth the price tag!

haqoH1vQ0pnNHLHaikm2SQ.text: Yummy bone marrow, and oysters. Nice classy place, and great service.

EcgmFdM6T7gkE_zAjFS0xQ.text: I had dinner at Sage a couple of months ago with co-workers.   I had the braised veal cheeks and the cheese plate. The veal cheeks were very good and tender. Nice atmosphere too.   While I enjoyed my meal I probably would only go back if it was expensed again.

BZV4rNx7a7fPcqLK6NE1AA.text: Whoa baby!  I have to thank my fellow Yelpers for this one because without your reviews, I probably would have gone right past Sage.  This restaurant was the only part of my experience at the Aria that was without flaw.    The decor of the restaurant is sexy, urban, chic.  Stroll past the imposing wine cases into an environment that closes out the casino completely and focuses on making your taste buds so very happy.  My first thumbs up goes to the bar staff.  Very well executed classic cocktails.  Though I did not sample the wines myself, another couple that were local, explained to me that they come to Sage just for the wine selection.  Try the Sazerac if you're inclined to enjoy something with some whiskey in it.  The bartender really enjoys making them and she made a beauty.  On to the food.  The amuse bouche was a generous spoon of a tuna tartare that was excellent.  It was the starter that let me know all you Yelpers had done me right.  I had the Waygu Beef Tartare.  It's served with little crisps of chocolate.  I would have never imagined that pairing, but it sure worked well.  An exceptional starter.  So how do you top that starter?  A Kobe Flatiron steak did the trick for me.  It was topped with some shaved truffle, baby carrots on top of a neat little potato deal.  The steak was perfectly prepared and carved for me to appreciate all of it's medium rareness.  The quality of the beef was apparent and it was exceptional.  I forgot what the little potato thing was, but it was very thinly sliced and transformed in such a way that it did not resemble a potato product in appearance.    While I was tempted to indulge in dessert, I knew I had a long evening ahead of me, so I enjoyed my Sazerac and promised myself I would be back, oh yes, I will be back :-)

iBqUHmhF2HDXDC8C-K7xuA.text: Wowsers!! This place was beyond what I'd ever imagine..The SNAKE RIVER FARMS NEW YORK STRIP (yes in all caps kind of good) was beyond words. It was so tender, juicy, succulent, any word that would describe pure bliss please add it to this review!!! The atmosphere mixed with the people at my table..Along with Bond our waiter..It was the dopest night ever! If you go ask for Bond he was amazing! Oh and Abstinthe..Have to try it, the green elixir!

bCYLfUbM8eURpDfYr8YUlw.text: The recent Vegas trip was all about exploring the restaurants in the new City Center, and Sage was one of our adventure.   The service, decor, ambiance are all first class, the food was good, but not the best we ever had.   Interestingly, I would rate the freebies the highest: the salmon tar-tare was very tasty and refreshing; the bacon roll was flaky, crunchy & even better w/butter & salt. I blamed myself not to ask for an additional one; :( and the chocolate butterscotch was smooth and creamy...yum!   For Appetizer, kusshi oysters are definitely "Must-Have"! The best of its kind! They are small, but fatty and juicy. The sauce is incredible as well. A 5-star here!   For entrees, I had the scallops with braised ox tail. Huge scallops tenderly seared with very rich braised oxtail. The mushroom and leafy veggie (don't know what it was, but it was good ) were soaked in the rich oxtail gravy and were actually the best part, in my opinion. I would give the scallops a solid 4-star.   My husband ordered Belgian Ale-Braised Short Rib. The short ribs were slowly braised, and were very tender. Honestly, they were good , but not the best  we have had in other places. Again, it was a rich dish with big portion, it made him so full that I had to help out :( We both agree that's a 3.5 star dish!

MHpJXVKQT_9HADI9EKDpWA.text: Sage delivered the best meal I had while in Vegas, and that included trips to the Mesa Grill, CraftSteak, Sensi, and Emeril's.  The service was first rate, very attentive, and never overly intrusive.  The restaurant's interior was beautiful, and lounge-like.  And the food was excellent.  The corn soup with crab that I had was wonderful; the American Kobe Skirt steak was perfectly cooked, bursting with flavor, and surrounded by some absolutely delicious crispy avocado balls.  The Pineapple Mousse I had for dessert was beautifully plated and a great cap to the evening.

OuaSfFDw-ffNjAHc1buymw.text: I love this restaurant - elegant decor, great service and the food is delicious! Instead of ordering an appetizer and a main course, I decided to order three appetizers. I started with the Yellowtail dish. It was basically yellowtail sashimi with truffles. It was an ok dish. I felt the truffles were a little overpowering. I couldn't really taste the fish.  My second dish was the Beef Tartar. OMG, it was sooo good. The beef was fresh and seasoned perfectly. Paired with crunchy bread, I almost licked the plate.  I ended my dinner with the Foie Gras Custard 'Brulee'. It was one of the most creative and delicious foie gras dishes ever. Loved every single bite of it.  I am giving it a four star rating because the Yellowtail dish was just alright and I just couldn't believe that after spending $100, I was still hungry.

nu_8jMSZPwQ2-1UthAXf_g.text: I took a friend here to celebrate her birthday prior to attending a show in Vegas.  We both ordered from the pre-theater menu, which was an incredible bargain at $49/each.  The service here was incredible--the timing of each course was absolutely perfect, the waiter was friendly and knowledgeable and all of our needs were anticipated.  Even before the courses started to arrive, Sage won me over with its delicious bacon bread, which should not be missed!  We also ordered a poached egg with crostini appetizer that was covered with some sort of truffle foam.  It was just fantastic and very beautifully presented.  Next came a bowl of fresh burrata with summer squash, a crispy sea bass and finally a white chocolate ganache dessert with blueberries and caramel corn.   Sage is my new favorite restaurant in Vegas.  I can't wait for my next visit!

AENg4CCs-HWy1KwbLr-Nng.text: We came to Sage especially for the Absinthe, they have 3 different ways that they prepare the Absinthe for you.  The one I ordered was the Russian way, which this is where they coat the glass with Absinthe and light it on fire, trap the vapors then give you a straw to inhale the Absinthe vapors.  If you ever wanted an instant drunk feeling without having to drink so much, go to Sage and ask for the Absinthe the Russian way.  My friends got the French way of Absinthe and that is where they drip water through a sugar cube onto the Absinthe.  That way was good too, but mine was better.  Freebasing your Absinthe is the way to go!  They have a huge selection of Absinthes to choose from , unless you know what you are looking for, ask for help.  The bartender was a jerk but knew what he was doing.  If you want a friendly guy at the bar, this is the wrong place!  This is more of a restaurant, but we didn't eat cause we only wanted to drink.

JVseG9DngVZqLGNH1-NcwA.text: Wow! The food was amazing.  We had the prix fixe which offered an appetizer, two smaller size entrees, and dessert for $89.  To start, I had the Foie Gras Custard Brulee - if you like foie gras, you MUST get this.  I think this definitely was the highlight of the meal.  The foie gras had a light whipped texture and since it was a brulee there was a hint of sweetness.  Next, I had the Ale Braised Short Rib and Maine Lobster Casoncelli.  After the Foie Gras, the rich short rib was a little much, although very good.  The casoncelli was good too.  The dessert was a little of a let down though.  I had the carrot cake and in general it was dry and had a very hard outer layer.    Great fine dining restaurant, date night/girls night, have the Foie Gras Custard Brulee

ENKtJrIViT256tRkeJuwcQ.text: Very impressive meal with outstanding service.   Overall, all the food had clean, well-balanced flavors. We ordered the foie gras custard brulee, duck, and 4 course chef's signature menu, with selections of the wagyu beef tartare, main dayboat scallops, iberico pork loin, and chocolate ganache and caramel tart.   Pretty much, as everyone else has noted, the custard brulee is a must-get. Surprisingly, it wasn't overly-rich. The duck was a bit on the salty side, but it was very good still. The wine helped to cut the saltiness. the beef tartare came with a perfectly poached egg yolk. The scallops were cooked perfectly. And I don't think anyone can go wrong with iberico....  If you're eating before a night out in vegas, I'd also recommend getting the french press coffee. It helped to keep me up for a night of clubbing. Regardless, I loved the food.

4Fv-lH3Mu43S6caJqjcqFA.text: this place had been on my go-to list for a while since i learned that it was a new venture by the owners/chef at my former favorite restaurant in chicago, Spring.  i finally came here with some friends for a bachlorette party last weekend. service was really good. the table ordered the prix fixe menu for $79.  i ordered the oyster appetizer, which was really fresh with just the right amount of brine. my friend upgraded to a foie gras brulee served with brioche bread, which was really creamy and smooth, definitely worth the $10 upgrade. for entrees, i ordered the scallop in braised short rib sauce. the scallops were perfectly cooked and caramelized, and the sauce with bits of short rib was succulent. my second entree was the 48 hour beef belly, which was melt in your mouth amazing.  for dessert, i ordered the strawberry tart, which was like spring on a plate.   i will be dreaming of food from here until i return.

Oy5UONqanYQDpTjAGpYaKQ.text: Sage continually delivers. I am a huge fan of their appetizers but you really can't go wrong with anything.

v-hvA0xLQZ3v5tN_NH_zLw.text: Really disappointed with Sage as it came highly recommended.  We had the $120 tasting menu and the food was mediocre at best.  Just too much going on each plate and it was not cohesive.  Seasonings and sauces were worse than average.  Amuse buche was very good, oysters.  King crab had too many components that did not work well together. Best dish is the scallop with the garlic panna cotta.  The lamb was over cooked and sweet breads were oily and did not belong on the plate.  The 48 hour beef belly was the most disappointing as the sauce had no flavor,  the belly ended up tasting fatty and the best part of the dish was the asparagus and almonds.  The chocolate mint soup was devine.  The desserts were a mess!  Best part of our meal werethe wine pairings.  The service was lacking as our waiter was too cool for his position.  He spoke ever so softly and was full of himself.  He spoke down to us and put down the other restaurant that recommended Sage.  Once he took our order we were serviced by the sommelier, bus boys and runners.  Waiter at one point scolds the bus boy at our table. Sage does a poor job of entertaining the diner.  Our time there was painful as dinner took 3 hours, we waited for our dessert for 20 minutes.  With so many great restaurants in Vegas, I would not recommend Sage. I want a refund of my time back.

qn4Ert-xEOWIPze-_UR1_g.text: Sage is an awesome restaurant for a date!  Went here with the gf and was a dope experience.  The setting/surrounding in this place is really psychadelic and classical so its a cool mix and vibe.  Def go for the table and not the bar-the bartenders can make interesting/mean drinks but the perks of eating a meal/appetizers at the tables are wayy better.  For example, at the table, we got a complimentary glass of rose moet each, foie gras free and a shot of cocoa (BOMB!) at the end of the meal.  Everything on the menu is awesome, loved the wagyu tartare with the gold flakes and venison.  Awesome meal and ambiance for little over 100$ for 2!  Usually pretty dead (customerwise tho) the 3 times I came.

grafvyZeoTq-cdTzrdeoCQ.text: Thanksgiving in Las Vegas was starting to become a tradition for us. 2 years ago we decided last minute to dine at Nobhill, one of Micheal Mina's restaurants, and we were disappointed. So this year I wanted to make sure I found a restaurant that would be absolutely delicious but I didn't want to get my hopes up. Sage was magnificent. Our server was great. She was able to describe every dish we had questions about. The fois gras brulee was one of the most amazing things I have ever tasted. Our server said she often has dreams about it and she's right, I do dream about it.

gaxcTOgUU5wfKKmHUpNe0A.text: Great food. Nice upscale and exclusive vibe without being too stuffy. Great bar too.

KimbSpoQtuAwiRfvbRv60w.text: The ambiance here is great and the service is pretty decent. The food, it was eh. We had a table of about 14 people and pretty much 90% of our table got the pre-set menu. The foie gras creme brulee was the best thing off that menu. The rest was not worth what we all paid for dinner. One of our friend had something else off the menu instead and he got food poisoning. Not good. Too expensive for blah food.

8NQ4I93ylC2sr-2NZCrZgA.text: Sage.  Saaage.  I planned a feast for my birthday.  5 restaurants in 1 day. The restaurant I was most excited to try? Sage.  I had read many reviews for this beautiful place inside of Aria in City Center, and had my plan already set.   We were the first people in that evening, as our reservations were for 5:00, which is when they open.  I really wish I could remember our servers name, she was SO friendly and helpful with any questions, and she would chat with us, without it being annoying or uncomfortable.    We had the octopus salad, steak salad, oysters, the (amazing) foie gras creme brulee, and the sweetbreads.  Everything was incredible.  Service was top notch, everything came out timely with great food descriptions (which are like lullaby's for me, soo soothing.)    While speaking to our server, (I WILL find out her name, because she deserves to be in this review) I mentioned that it was my birthday, and also that I was a culinary student. Later in the night I asked who the chef was that evening, she told me that Shawn McClain was in, and he then came out and spoke with us.  It was such an honor to meet such a wonderful and successful chef!  We ended our meal with the canneles de bordeaux.  It was an incredible night filled with amazing food, quality service, and happiness.  We will be returning again in June, and I can't wait!

t-MuVHoNIBKpB7ktxXB84g.text: Beautiful restaurant... We had a bit of a table conflict.. But in the end all turned out great... First the bar... Friendly but not fake bar tenders.. Great music and atmosphere.. Ordered a bottle of Farniente ...my boyfriends favorite ... Then moved to dinner and stumbled across the 4 corse tasting menu.. Incredible mix of flavors ... We both ordered 4 courses and got to taste 8 ... Perfect portions and food for your eyes and your soul.   This is a top notch Vegas restaurant!

pVjm_UnWGXGeffjBx-Jtrw.text: How is this place four stars? If anything it two stars and crazily overpriced.  I completely understand that we are in Las Vegas, however $24 for King crab appetizer that consists of three minuscule pieces of king crab is far from any sort of value. If you were going to have any appetizer, I would recommend the octopus which was delicious.   Moving onto the main courses, I would recommend the short rib or maybe a piece of fish however neither are anything to write home about.    I would stick with STK or Ocean.

CvTQhwBhPIX2CNInjTyaLw.text: I celebrated my birthday here a few days ago. My server James provides exceptional service.  The wine menu was listed in which every meat had an option of two of more wines. Which was great and saved time so I eat their delicious French bread. I order salmon dish that nearly blew my socks off! It was seared in the outside a tender on the inside. If you love a calm elegant environment and good food this is the place for you.

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Celebrating my birthday
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Salmon! Oh delicious salmon.

19qud9Vvmbh9dLlbhfZvoQ.text: Amazing service and martinis.   One of the best spots I came across in Vegas.  I recommend a visit.

5NhObAoA0obKdRiBlXPIbw.text: We had our heart set on eating somewhere inside Aria because it was too beautiful. After browsing a few, we spied Sage tucked into the corner. We perused the menu for less than 2 minutes and decided this would be it. It was the 36 hour Waygu short rib that did it for me.  Our waiter was knowledgeable and smartly attuned to what we were expecting in this experience. He read us like a book. We skipped apps and went right to entrees and dessert. For us, that was the only way we could have made it through the dinner and I'm usually a pretty big tasting menu kind of gal. Bread course (we're from Texas, we opted for both kinds) and amuse bouche were consumed quickly, I didn't even have time for pics!  Once again, I had the 36 hour short ribs with white asparagus and roasted turnips. Licked that plate clean. The short rib was spiced just right and was very tender. For dessert, I had to have the foie gras candy bar. At first, I wasn't quite sure if I liked it because it was just so busy for a dessert, but by the last bite I knew it was really good.  Ambiance was spot on with the feel of the entire hotel. Classy, sexy and just the right amount of chatter. I would come back for this.

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Foie gras candy bar
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 36 hour Waygu short rib

0FOFFEanwhJsnDscfSO5qA.text: I wanted to try something new and different since I was celebrating my birthday in Vegas! This restaurant came highly recommended by Chef concierge Hakkan at the VDARA where I stayed. I've never really had french american food before so I thought i would give this a try.   The restaurant itself is romantic and gorgeous! The dimmed lights with lavender undertones was so pretty! All the artwork throughout the restaurant was amazing....The table we had was part booth with pillows so comfy loved it!   The bread basket they started us with was infused with bacon and they also had this olive oil dipping sauce soooo tasty! For appetizer we had the pork belly....I'm not a huge fan of pork but they way it was done it was really good. I got the Red Snapper with veggies and potatoes for dinner....omg it was amazing! My friend got the salmon which was pretty good too....and for dessert we shared their version of Strawberry Shotrcake...which I adored!!  My only complaint was the service was lacking,,,,took the waitress 10 min to come and greet  us and then another 10 min before we had menus and water....and then additional time to order after that.  DOS: 3/7/15

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Strawberry Shortcake!!
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sage in Las Vegas at Aria

p3zYU9JocNtUSJAL6qGzHQ.text: Try the green garlic soup!  Skip the alaskan king crab and asparagus salad.  It's small tempura crab bits and its definitely not worth the price!  Total disappointment.  Beecher's farm whey fed pork loin was AMAZING!  The pork loin was like butter in my mouth.  NY strip ordered to medium rare was perfection, but i think the star of the show was their la ratte potatoes.  Creamy potatoes probably loaded with cream and butter.  Needed a bit of salt though.  They gave us a complimentary hot chocolate and it was divine!  Hot chocolate infused with THYME.  It had a really nice after taste.. Slightly sweet with a very light herby taste.  Wish we could of gotten more to go!

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Alaskan king crab and asparagus salad- skip it!  Not worth $24
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beechers whey fed pork loin

CkaQqEetRtoRXm9mslr4qA.text: The food here was quite good, but there was poor execution on NYE. They have us no flexibility in substitutions on tasting menu which was not surprising, but they served us starting out with the wrong items. Also, the dessert course took almost 30min from main course. I suspect they we were making in batches and we suffered cause we were among the first seated. The server apologized a few times and blamed back of house for the issues.  The Iberico pork was one of the best main dishes I had in Vegas. Tender, savory, with bursts of tangy fruit bits on plate.

NC5B3MLqSwTSCbnc2NPznQ.text: We absolutely love the Wagyu Beef Tartar & The Fois Gras Brulee. So good!!! We came here for dinner and loved it, so we came back another time for appetizers and drinks at the bar. We would definitely recommend this place. The service is excellent! You can make reservations on Open Table. Can't wait to go back!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fois Gras Brûlée - June 2016
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Steak tartar - June 2016

JS7uqPZChmN1TVbHArde3A.text: Define: sage  /saj/ Noun:  An aromatic plant (Salvia officinalis) of the mint family, with grayish-green leaves that are used as a culinary herb. A profoundly wise man. Adjective Having, showing, or indicating profound wisdom.  This place totally deserves its name!  We didn't do the tasting menu (which I regret a little), and also didn't get any cocktails (also, a miss - they looked amazing and I overheard people at the table next to us praising them). I think that our menu choices weren't really "sage", we got some wine, I got catfish dish and my fiance got a Kobe steak.  Both dishes were great - presentation, taste, just the right wise combination of spices, perfect portion size. However, I must say that I liked the sides more than I liked the proteins - I had amazing pea puree and my fiance's parsnip puree made me reach out to his plate a few times.   However, the reviews of dishes in this restaurant are irrelevant - their menu keeps changing... The dishes from previous reviews are not longer available. But I am sure, that if you take a tasting menu, you will not regret!

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kobe Beef
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Red snapper
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chef&#39;s complements

wTcBD-XFNuq4vZOANQmqQQ.text: Very interesting place. They claim to be an American restaurant, which is very True. However it has an interesting twist. For example, their menu has a lot of what you would expect at a good steak house.   Also, The atmosphere is element and darker. Again what you expect from a steak house. However, with some modern background and lights. Very nice concept   Food is well above average and the service is superior.

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. NY strip.
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Front dining area.
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bar area.

gFszfcCGDCJXZZkCJJQRVg.text: I had high hopes for this place but I ended up walking out very underwhelmed .  As the reviews recommended, we ordered wagyu beef tartare and the foie gras brulee for starters, and ordered the veal cheeks for the entree.  Beef tartare was okay, nothing spectacular. I've definitely had better. The sauce was a bit overpowering.   The foie gras brulee was the biggest disappointment of the night. Now, I was already aware from the reviews that this dish is a bit on the sweeter side to be enjoyed as an appetizer. Regardless of the sweetness, I feel like this dish just simply doesn't... work. The dish was definitely too sweet for an appetizer. But the taste of foie gras did not get along well with the creme brulee , and was off-putting to be eaten as a dessert. And I've had foie gras many times, in different forms. The idea was nice, but the flavors were just... clashing. The sauce on top (I can't recall if it was blackberry or blueberry) did not work well either. I tried the dish as an appetizer AND as a dessert, but neither way worked. No matter how hard I tried to like it, I could not get past 3 bites and neither could my date.  Veal cheeks - These were good, but definitely not worth $41. Honestly you can get something similar to this elsewhere for around $25. The portion was small too. You can pay 5 more bucks and get a 6 oz filet mignon at a decent steakhouse.  All in all, the meal wasn't bad, but definitely left more to be desired. For the same amount of money, I'd go elsewhere.

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Veal cheeks- good, but not worth $41
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Foie gras brulee.. Too sweet for an appetizer, but too strong to be a dessert
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Wagyu beef tartare (4/5)

8B1MRF5IZJhE0jJa-MmSqQ.text: I'll refrain from being overly critical.  The food was pretty good.  We ordered 3 to 4 courses each for a table of 4 with a bottle of wine.  The service was not exactly over the top, nor was it any worse than the last time I went to a chain restaurant such as California Pizza Kitchen where I bring my young boys.    We came for an anniversary dinner with close friends on a quick trip away from the kids.  We told our waitress about the occasion.  A birthday was being celebrated next to us, with a candle for the birthday boy.  For our table?  Nothing.  Perhaps I should have spelled it out a little bit more.  I guess in this day and age of having to spell everything out, a la carte, personal check lists, that's just the way things should be run nowadays.  Man, do I sound old.  The bread service, where CPK would win in this case, came at a random time.   The sommelier (or maybe he wasn't a som) didn't seem to like that I was seeing if the wine would be palatable for my wife..."Is there something wrong with the wine?" He asked somewhat irritated.  I said, "No, but I'm trying to figure out if my wife would like it..."   I'm no som, but I know what my wife likes.  The gentleman said nothing after my concern and, after I succumbed to the pressures of his irritable tone of voice by saying "it's good", proceeded to pour with robotic mechanics.  Did I mention I like border collies.  They're pretty intelligent and task driven, but if not trained they are known to nip joggers and be somewhat socially shy.  The delicious food seemed to be on the heavier side. I guess "New American" may be more like French Bistro with an Asian/Mediterranean mix.  There was nothing subtle about the flavors, so what you ask for is basically what you get.  If I were to suggest to myself if I had a time machine, would be to order 3 instead of 4 entrees, don't come here for special occasions but if you do have a check list of items you would like,  and avoid tasting the wine with an opinion unless you know a specific wine that you know is off their huge wine list.  If you want decent food and, maybe, serviceable service, then this place is for you.    Thank you for your time.

ieDQMwyxlXFg7ww7WYO6Qg.text: Sage is truly a hidden gem in Las Vegas but there were a few glitches on my visit. Went in on a Saturday night for my boyfriends birthday and it was not full. I had made a reservation and was seated right away. I went during restaurant week and I took full advantage of it their menu. For starters I ordered a dirty martini and when I received it, it was not dirty at all. I told my waiter and he told me he could bring me more olive juice on the side or make me a new one. I opted out for just the olive juice but quickly regret it when it warmed my drink a little. Wish he would've just told me he would get me a new drink, the concept of bringing olive juice over was slightly strange. I ordered the roasted carrots for my first course and it was the perfect balance between sweet and salty, nutty and earthy. I loved it! For my main entree I had the skirt steak. I ordered it medium and received a well done steak! I told our waiter and he said it looked medium well when clearly there was no pink! He asked if I wanted to have them run it again I said no because I hate putting others into trouble and I didn't want to eat at different times with my boyfriend. It's very inconvenient. I also wish our waiter was a little more supportive. When offering to run things again it seemed more as if he was just saying it because he had to. I felt like he didn't take us too seriously. My boyfriend and I are in our early twenties and I usually don't care but when I'm paying a little more than usual I want everything the way I asked it with out having to ask twice or question myself. Anyways, it was a good steak and would've been better had it not been over done. I also had the passion fruit Mousse which was nice and refreshing. Deff recommend this place over any other over crowded restaurant in Las Vegas, will be back but I will put my foot down next time. Three stars for the mediocre service, would've been a five had they fixed their mistakes the right way.

DqzRE-Xm00a3yvrGAosRdQ.text: My boyfriend and I spent our three year anniversary at Sage this weekend. They really made it special! We started and had a glass of wine at the bar, I recommend this. The bartender was friendly but not over bearing! And the bar itself is so pretty to look at! Once we sat at the perfect table, the service and food started. You MUST get a wine pairing from Christina! She knows her stuff and added that extra touch that put our evening over the top. The brulee foie gras was amazing, melted on my mouth! Duck confit salad, sturgeon and both the desserts were out of this world. Yes, it's pricy for the portion size. However, every bite is worth the price! If you are looking for an unique experience on the strip and a food vacation. You must visit Sage!

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Foie gras candy bar that they personalized for our special celebration!

KZYqTp4DprTLJjoSkV-LtQ.text: A five star dining experience in every sense.   We had the 4 course signature chef's menu complete with wine pairings. My husband and I ordered different things so we could maximize our tastes, and I have to start by saying that everything I tasted was delicious and memorable.   Highlights for me included the luscious foie gras brulee, the scallops with braised oxtail, and the pork loin with spaetzle. The pork was paired perfectly with a 2002 Rioja I'm going to have to track down somewhere.   The restaurant aesthetic is modern and chic, in line with the rest of the Aria. I also really appreciated the kind and attentive service! There are plenty of wonderful upscale dining options in Vegas, and I think Sage can hang with the best of them.

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Incredible pork loin over spaetzle.
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Unique and wonderful foie gras brûlée. One of my favorite dishes!
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beautiful Meyer lemon cheesecake. It was paired with a lovely raisiny dessert wine.

R9WEg3IZSES0JLI_RhKbvw.text: Came for dinner before the 9:30 Zarkana show.  The interior lighting is dimly-lit which gives the restaurant a romantic ambiance :]  Ordered the 4 course Chef's tasting menu ($89) with wine pairing ($44).  Not bad for the price at all!!! The presentation of each dish was exquisite (see pictures) and everything was perfect :] Left with a full tummy too!   Sourdough/bacon bread served with sea salt and butter  * Pear Salad - 5/5 * Oysters with Tobasco sorbet - 5/5 (A MUST TRY) * Wagyu Beef Tartare w/ bread - 4.5/5 (a bit heavier than I expected) * Jumbo Scallops - 4/5  * Grilled Octopus with smoked potato puree- 5/5 * 48 hour Beef Belly with sweet potato puree-5/5  * Iberico Pork Loin- 4.5/5  * Olive Oil ice cream- 5/5 (SO GOOD with the wine pairing)  * Green Apple Mousse (Substitution)- 4/5  * White Chocolate Soup - 5/5 (PERFECT way to cleanse our palette after an amazing meal :])

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Grilled Octopus with smoked potato purée
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Iberico Pork Loin
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 48 hour beef belly

pUIlov-7FgevPD2Ja1UcMQ.text: If you desire the luxury of how the other half lives, make a visit to Sage. The staff was friendly and absolutely attentive. From start to finish, you are never neglected. My recommendation is to start off with the Cotton Candy cocktail; a requirement in my opinion. It is served at your table with a ball of pink cotton candy and the cocktail poured over it.  This delicious libation is not overly sweet and I can tell you, one is not enough. Though there are so many things I can boast about regarding the cuisine, the star of the menu was the Iberico "Secreto" Pork. Personally, I had to slow down my pace to savor every bit of this savory and tender meat. Complimented with kale and Asian pear, this dish found a perfect balance of sweet, savory and bitter. Though I was too full to order dessert, I did finish out with Absinthe served traditionally over a sugar cube. There is the option of serving with fire and ice in case one needs more flare in their serving. The dress code is "dress casual" so I wore a polo and khakis. I did some in three piece suits and others in jeans and a button down. As for cost, dining on a budget is not the name the game. Though the menu options are pricey, this is one restaurant to splurge. If there is one fantastic night of food and drinks you seek, make it Sage.

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Iberico &#34;Secreto&#34; Pork with Kale and Asian Pear

NYZApZ2CWOmGpqc4NSqNEQ.text: The scallops, the oxtail, the short ribs....all my memories of this place invoke fantastic food, great presentation and most of all personable, professional service. The decor inspires an overall intimate evening.  Sit at the bar with Aaron to improve your knowledge of spirits and enjoy a special comradeship between bartender and patron.  Do not come to Vegas and miss this experience.

SZ40MT5kVz6-RdveHnbVvw.text: I was recently on a business trip in Las Vegas and a group of us went to dinner at Sage, which is located in Aria. The atmosphere was great.  The staff were all very attentive and pleasant. The menu changes every so often, so there is a chance that the menu will change by the time anyone reads this review. Hike the menu does change it isn't extensive so you don't have pages of items to decide between which is nice.  I ordered the Grilled Wagyu Hanger Steak with crispy potatoes, salsa brava and wild leeks. It was one of the most amazing steaks I have eaten. It melted in my mouth and was the perfect portion as to not be overly filling and just enough to satisfy my appetite.  I did not partake in dessert, but I did partake in the Absinthe bar. While I have enjoyed absinthe in the past, I have never enjoyed it presented as an experience. When you order it, they bring a cart to your table and prepare it for you table side. The brand, flavor, region of absinthe that you select is poured. Then a sugar cube is soaked in it, then placed on an absinthe spoon and lit on fire. Once the flame has burned a certain amount of time they then pour ice cold water over it to fill the rest of you glass and voila!   I was very pleased with the service, food and entire experience.  I can't wait to go back.

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Absinthe with sugar cube burning.
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Grilled Wagyu Hanger Steak

Np7N-seu1meENVzEgaJB2g.text: Went here for a nice fancy dinner with my boyfriend to celebrate our anniversary. Can definitely say that it was really nice fine dining. The restaurant was elegant and classy. The lighting gave it a romantic ambience. We made reservations earlier in the day, so we were able to get seated right away. Service was really good. I really liked our waiter, he was always there to get anything we needed and our food came out fast.  We chose to do the tasting menu, where it's a 7 course meal for each of us. All of the food was DELICIOUS! Even though the portions were smaller, we were fully stuffed by the end of the meal. Every single course was unique and flavorful. And each plate that came out looked like a piece of art. We also received one course of oysters on the house and a palate cleanser sorbet before our dessert. So you can say we had 9 courses overall! They paced our course really well, so our next course came out right after we finished the current one. We also ordered cocktails that were very well made. I had the cotton candy and the glass came out full with cotton candy, into which our waiter poured the alcohol mix on top of. How cool! I would say give at least 2 hours for this dining experience, because we were cutting it ind of close in trying to get to the show we were going to watch at another casino.  Since it was our anniversary, they also wrote 'Happy Anniversary' at the top of our dessert. It was a really nice gesture :)  Overall, it was a really great fine dining experience and would recommend!

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States

iLRuexwhTqJQv3J5XQztJQ.text: ARIA has some legit dining options. Well done on their part. Sage was one of the best dining experiences my wife and I have had this year, and that's saying a lot.   We were greeting at the door courteously and professionally and the staff was totally on point. Our server who's name I cannot recall did not miss a beat and her support from the kitchen and Sommelier was fantastic.   The decor inside is romantic and dark. We enjoyed it. My wife's gown pretty much matched their aesthetic exactly which was cool.   We opted for the Five Course Summer tasting w/wine. We also added two cocktails on the front and one on the back (mistake of mine but not Sage's more to come on that). Since I'm a glutton we also added Wagyu Tartar.   We know our food, we love our wine. This meal did not miss a beat. I won't go into detail of each dishes construction or flavor but every single bite was a delight. Major kudos are due to the Sommelier for being adventurous with her pairings and really stepping out from what I've grown to expect from a lot of tasting menus with wine. She really surprised us with a few choices and even though we are not partial to whites the ones she poured knocked our socks off. Also, very generous pours of 8-10oz.   The one mistake I did during this meal was order Absinthe as a final cocktail. I wish I hadn't. My wife wasn't finishing her wine, I was trying to do it for her. By the end of the meal and the Absinthe I needed help walking to our hotel room.   Overall 5/5. I mentioned the food, the wine, the staff...one thing you really need to keep in mind at Sage is the value. Their tasting menu is one of the less pricey in Vegas. You get a lot for what you give.

eDsL6qQArK2aw1yzNaUaVQ.text: Food at the restaurant was great, but our waitress was horrible.  Our group almost walked out but our bread and water servers were nice.  You ever had that feeling that you were being judged in a high end store?  That's what that waitress was like.  Apparently she's never read Nordstrom's book.  We had appropriate attire and we were not rowdy.  She paid more attention to parties of 2 or 3.  When we finally got her attention, she just waved a finger at us to signal will be there in a minute.  Least she could do was walk by to directly tell us you'll help us in a minute.  You'll enjoy this restaurant.  I hope you don't get this waitress on a Sat night.  I had better service at In and Out Burger.

2E4CPy8RHeAONNCIpvWyoQ.text: The waiter was very friendly and the atmosphere was great. The $130 5-course chef's tasting menu (mine consists of lightly smoked ora king salmon, seared foie gras, maine day-boat scallops, Japanese f1 wagyu, and chocolate pot de creme) was phenomenal. It was the perfect amount - not too much, not too little. Every dish was perfected and unique. My only disappointment is the bread. The mini baguettes, although not soggy, were way too hard. Overall great dining experience. Given the courses I would say it was well worth the $130. Would recommend to others.

76dkaRmb2wd3bhTKBBvOrQ.text: Perhaps this is a case of setting expectations that were too high, but I was greatly looking forward to dining at Sage and although the food was fairly good the overall experience left a lot to be desired.   First of all, the table we were sat at was in a very weird location that felt like a table shouldn't have been there. The lighting was sharp and bizarre and honestly made me feel a bit queasy. Then, the service was slow and inattentive. It made me feel like we didn't matter or they didn't care that we were there.  First I had the Spring Arugula Salad. I knew I'd be having a steak so I wanted a light appetizer. It was... fine. Nothing you can't get anywhere else. I then had the Wagyu New York Strip. It was well cooked and seasoned and tasted nice, with a good texture. But the service and weird table were almost enough to ruin the whole evening.

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States

b0yv7Hgem2fEBQsbWkjAow.text: Its not often that I leave reviews, but this place just blew my mind. The staff were amazing at taking care of my friends and I, they were very professional at everything and any request I had they did it immediately. Every dish that we ordered was excellent. We started with the beef tartar and the Gem salad. The tartar and the salad are definitely the 2 dishes I would come back for. My favorite dish overall was the scallops. I would recommend this place to anybody, and I'm looking forward to going back.

L6NgsFVSgXnuvWXgNWkbUw.text: We had 10pm reservations for a Monday night after being in Vegas for a trade show for a few days. We had heard great things about the Foie Gras Chocolate Bar. We arrived around 9:40 for the reservation and let them know we were here. They said they were just going to set up the table for us and it would be a few minutes. It was just us 4 so I didn't think it would take too long considering that and they didn't have any one else waiting for a table besides us. Well we finally got seated 20 minutes later after asking why it was taking so long. When we went to the dining room, there were a few tables open so it was a little annoying that it took them so long to seat us. They made up for it by offering us some champagne on the house.   The dining room was beautiful. Dimly lit and well decorated. It's perfect if you're looking for a nice date spot.   We only came for dessert so we ordered two of the foie gras chocolate bars and one of the foie gras creme brulee. I'm not a huge fan of foie gras but the chocolate bar was great. It came with caramelized popcorn on top. It wasn't overly sweet either. The foie gras creme brulee wasn't my favorite. It was a savory creme brulee which was a weird mix for me.   Overall the dessert stop was fine. I'd probably try here for dinner but skip the creme brulee foie gras.

zeRFvwmQK355MbRSzDxFbA.text: We had a big group dinner and reserved the back room. I had the: - Hamachi Crudo Salad: very good, would order again - Scallops: delicious, would definitely recommend - Waygu Filet: delicious, would definitely order again

QXe4mnpzWj8WW0nuiNhDrA.text: Top Notch Service  After a five year gap between visits it was nice to see that Sage is still bringing wonderful food and excellent service to Aria. The kusshi oysters were clean and juicy and the sorbet/mignonette was tasty. Definitely have the foie gras brulee for a special treat. Both the secreto pork and Maine day boat scallops were prepared wonderfully and not a bite was left on our plates. Friendly, attentive and incredibly competent service from Virginia. Colton was incredibly engaging and helpful as Sommelier. Drink your dessert and try one of the absinthe choices and preparations - you won't see much like it again!!

4c05sY_UnGuoWSSTBmarvA.text: We celebrated our 30 year anniversary here and the food service and atmosphere was amazing. Our server Wayne did and amazing job to make us feel welcomed . The desert was awesome as well highly recommended

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States

sdoEwwtQ1Ct_AMPUATLkCA.text: Loved my experience here! The food was delicious. Service was great. I came here for my anniversary and they definitely made us feel very special. Everything from beginning to end including just making our reservation was great. Perfect date night!

ePrGat8yphfv5XxfI7N21A.text: After hanging around on the Strip we decided to finally check out Sage after hearing so much about it. We came and ordered some cocktails and really enjoyed ourselves.    This is a pretty swank spot in a great area.

MgP-G2-fczdvp7z1Dfwpng.text: Holy-moly if the people weren't beyond nice here, then the food alone would be worth it.  But all of the people that helped us AND the food were BOTH incredible.  This place has swiftly become one of our top 2 in LV.  The slow poached egg (served w potato and toasted bread) was one of the best things I've ever, ever tasted. Wayne was our server and after 2 minutes he felt like family.  We adored his sweet nature and helpfulness.  Jacob was fantastic, filling our water before it was even close to empty and swiftly helping wherever he was needed.  Robert brought us champagne when he found out it was our 10yr Anniversary. He also checked in a couple times and made us feel genuinely welcome.  We really love this place and can't wait to come back.

NliOkaCF-8gPrhhM0L_gHw.text: Had the pleasure of dining in Sage at Aria. We decided to try the Chef's Tasting Menu as we had not been there before and thought it would be a great option to sample the full essence of the restaurant. Sage is one of those places I've walked by a thousand times but never went in. I always thought it looked dark and sexy and it is. Sage is brought to you by James Beard award winning chef Shawn McClain who's other Las Vegas offerings include FIVE50 Pizza Bar and the new Libertine Social at Mandalay Bay. To be fair McClain stops in about twice a year. The chef is the very talented Chris Heisenger. It's considered New American Cuisine with an emphasis on California local harvests. The amuse bouche was a tasty Kuushi Oyster with Tabasco Sorbet and Tequila Mignonette,  delicious indeed! That wasn't on the menu so it was a nice start and surprise. As the dinner went on, each course was better than the next. The Ora King Salmon as the perfect first course and was followed by my personal favorite dish at Sage, the Oyster Beef Tartare. All of the other offerings were outstanding and complimented each other well. This menu was thought out and flowed like mountain spring. Service was flawless and friendly. Each dish was described to the detail and preparation. A wine pairing is offered but we declined. The cocktail program at Sage is among the best in Las Vegas and no one does a better Absinthe preparation in the country. Dinner was $150 and the wine pairing is offered for an additional $100. This menu does change as to what is in season and available. I highly recommend Sage and it's twice the culinary experience than E, by Jose Andres. Go and enjoy!

NMzqLJCsNfRivX_w3gBneA.text: My first trip to Vegas, it was my grandmas 80th birthday. Sage was our #1 pick for bday dinner and they did not disappoint!   Drinks were creative, tasteful, and strong ;).   There were multiple ways to dine - caviar, al a carte, or fixed. There was even a vegan menu. The most popular dish of the night were the scallops and the short rib. Short rib was braised for 36 hours. I'm a vegetarian - I had one of each item on the seasonal menu. The Heirloom Tomato Salad - light, fresh, aromatic. Sunchoke Tartare - first time for everything; rich flavors and smooth textures. Garnished with a cool rice cake. Finally, roasted eggplant - eggplant is not usually my first choice but this one was cooked to perfection in a sweet bbq sauce mixed with mushrooms and broccoli. Crushed it.   Dessert was so special - the staff came out and wished my Grandma happy birthday.   Super classy. Very delicious. 5 stars.

UFuziJW2spJvCMYflQA5Xw.text: Nice birthday dinner. The server Leilahi was very helpful to us , we had nice cocktails and we shared everything. Good experience but pricey. You pay for the great service and the amazing decor of course. Will come back and recommend for sure.

vy0Snh9849QiuL8-qzEKqg.text: Solid 4 stars due to the ambiance and the service; both were excellent. The food wasn't bad, as I had the wagyu strip steak with a side of mash. Not the best steak I've had, but it got the job done. Of interest is they don't have sides on the menu, they expect the additional stuff that comes with the meal (veggies and such) to do the trick... But I still ordered the mash and it was good. The one thing I wasn't a big fan of were the oysters; can't say I would order those again.  The price was reasonable too, so in all I would say it's worth a visit here.

4LB-WGdmfREDx4TUisnxTQ.text: Exterior = 5/5 This is a bar and restaurant located on the first floor of Aria. It was a little difficult to locate at first, but we found it tucked away in the corner, near the lobby and Tetsu. There isn't really a waiting area, unless you sit near the check in line. For us, we didn't have to wait since we wanted to go to the bar (and there was space).   Interior = 5/5 Lighting was more on the dim side which set a nice relaxing mood. Music and other customer conversations weren't too loud so I could still converse with my boyfriend. I did notice that they were setting up some live music (we got there around 6:30pm on a Saturday), so that was probably for later. Tables were spaced out nicely, and there was a good amount of setting at the bar. We didn't find space, so we took a nice table near the back. My boyfriend mentioned he could see table spacing issue if the bar area was more packed.  Service = 5/5 Server was quick to come and ask for what we liked. We didn't go with food, since we had dinner plans, and we opted for the drink menu. When we did order our drinks, he poured them at our table so we were able to enjoy the experience as if we were sitting at the bar - which I really liked.  Order = 5/5 Smoke: 5/5 Boyfriend ordered this, and it was tasty. It came served in a bottle filled with smoke, with the liquor at the bottom. The server then opened the bottle and poured its contents into a waiting glass. The smoke poured out along with the drink and reminded me of dry ice. When we went to drink it, you could still smell the smoke (sounds weird but actually was really nice). Even the after taste had a little smokey flavor which was oddly enjoyable for me since I thought I would be turned off by it. The drink went down smooth and the after taste was a nice ending to each sip.  Cotton Candy: 5/5 I ordered this and wanted to come here specifically for this drink since it looked interesting on Yelp and the Aria tablet in our room. When I looked at what it was composed of I just read citrus and sugar. I was sold. When the drink came, it was cotton candy sitting in a martini glass. The server then poured the liquor slowly over the cotton candy, and I was smiling as I watched it melt till it became this pink liquid. I like the balance it had, since the tartness of the citrus was balanced out with the sweetness of the cotton candy. I enjoyed sipping it and trying to find the flavors.  Overall = 5/5 I was a nice place to go for evening drinks. The ambiance and menu options were great for a relaxing chat. I did wish that they had longer hours, since they are not open on Sundays and usually only open evenings only. I will have to come back and try the restaurant next time - though I will make a point to grab a drink since our first two were a hit.  Hint = If you are concerned about restaurant lines, go early and grab a seat in the bar area while it is nice and spacious.

7s6Uf0jZwP7K_twHff0Nsw.text: Holy! Food here is absolutely delicious. We tried their all star Wagyu tartar, wagyu NY steak, chicken dish, veal cheeks, and a few others. They were all out of this world. Service was a bit slower and we had to figure out where our server is and when he will take our order or bring our check etc. atmosphere is phenomenal.

m53eAqyPdtMTZIJDfJWzSQ.text: Most amazing dinner in Vegas. A must for a beautiful dinner with your significant other or a group of friends. We did a double date dinner and had the chef's tasting menu with wine pairing. Omfg, my mouth loved me. Every signal item was just wonderful. Ambience was perfect. Service was superb. Worth every penny.

1gR_fp20aV4cVqzGGTtwVA.text: Best place we ate at in LasVegas this week during CES. I had the tasting menu, which includes options for all four courses. I had the faugras brulee, divers scallops, wagyu, and  German Forest cake. My favorite were the brulee and the scallops. The brulee was very smooth and creamy with the thinnest crust on top. The flavor was unique blend of sweet (mostly) with a touch of rich savory from the liver part. The pan seared scallops are a normal item but these were just very nicely done.   The only things I didn't like about this nicely appointed restaurant are that the food takes a bit longer to come out than i would have expected. Also, I thought the wine list was overpriced. Even using the "2x normal retail" rule, they are super high.   All that said, this could easily be a five star with just a little more quickness and tuning. And, maybe the prices for wine are just my problem :-)  So, next time you're feeling flush, and you're in LV near the Aria Hotel, give it a shot!

Z6oI1hSkw-YoMufIgOIKMQ.text: I've been dying to try out Chef Shawn McClain's new restaurant... and when I found myself spontaneously going to Vegas for my spring break, I HAD to make a reservation for Sage. To be honest, I had really high expectations coming into this meal. I was definitely not disappointed.   The food was delicious, portion size just right, and pricing not too bad for Vegas. I especially liked the amuse bouche, which was the perfect way to start the meal. I also loved the bread that came with the meal (very reminiscent of the bacon brioche that is served at Melisse in Los Angeles).  For appetizers, I got the poached eggs with shaved truffles and country bread. Oh my god. I didn't know what country bread was until I ordered this... basically its super deep fried bread, aka. AMAZINGNESS!!!!!! I was afraid that the poach egg would be too simple, too plain, not impressive enough. BUT, instead, the flavors and texture of the poached egg complimented the umami taste of the truffles. Overall, this dish was just perfect. The oiliness of the bread was subdued by the soft creaminess of the poached egg yolk.  We also ordered the foie gras creme brulee, since foie gras has been deemed illegal in Cali..... I've been so deprived of this fatty goodness. I was hesitant about ordering this at first, fearing that the foie + egg would be too sweet and too creamy. However, the consistency and taste was just right. The layer of crunchy burnt sugar on top of the fluffy foie custard was perfection. In addition, there were blood oranges thrown in, giving the custard more depth.   For the entree, I got the chicken entree with braised celery and truffled sausage. Boy oh boy. The chicken was tender, the sauce was amazing, and the truffled sausage was sooo tasty. I'm never been a huge fan of white meat (woo juicy dark meat!).. but this piece of chicken breast was so tender and moist that I forgot for a split second that I was eating white meat!!  Overall, this was a great food experience. Only reason why this didn't 5 stars is that the service was a bit iffy. The servers weren't very attentive and we had to keep flagging them down to refill our waters and take our order. With that being said, it may have just been a down day. I'm excited to come and try the tasting menu next time that I am in Las Vegas!

-FUohWLpW5RUV_FfeXjjxA.text: Wow!  This place has excellent service, excellent food and nice decor in the Aria Hotel.  Be sure to ask for Bond-awesome waiter.  One of our fellow Yelpers had recommended him and he was great!  We had the 4 course meal and started off with the foie gras brulee (yum!).  Our next course was the grilled octopus followed by the 48 hour beef belly (soooo tender and delicious).  To end the meal, I had the milk chocolate medallion with raspberry coulis and dark chocolate.  Oh yeah, the amuse bouche was lamb tartar with champagne grapes.  Delicious!  This place is comparable to OC's Marche Modern.

zGiZujXK_szh0rjajpo7Ow.text: Too long, didn't read? WAY overpriced and overhyped for mediocre food and pretty crummy service.   The long of it: We were seated at 9pm for an 8:15 reservation. In the bar. I only got a peek at the restaurant because I used the restroom. A server came over and asked if we wanted water. Five minutes later he came and filled two glasses, ran out of water and came back some time later to fill the other two glasses.   Drinks were probably the highlight of the night, my friend got a really tasty jalapeno cucumber cocktail and my husband's old fashioned was on point. However, I ordered a glass of red wine, which they poured into the "general wine glass" which was on the table. My friend's husband ordered a white wine and his was in the same glass. I thought it was pretty odd and asked the server why they didn't have red wine glasses. They do. If you buy a bottle. Well for $22/glass I DID buy the bottle and you know it, plus I called you out on (what I consider) a tacky cost-cutting cop out: bring me a red wine glass. Bertucci's serves wine in the appropriate stemware. The fine dining restaurant in the Aria Resort and Casino can't get themselves together to figure out a wine glass??   Food was fine, the husbands definitely chose the better options with the beef belly and the short ribs. My rabbit was good but my friend's halibut was tasteless and overcooked. Dessert was a major flop of small deconstructed disappointments. I had a really excellent cappuccino though.   The more we discussed it, the more disappointed each of the four of us considered the experience. And it definitely wasn't sticker shock. We love finding great restaurants and paying for exceptional service and amazing food. This was just a Vegas markup. I wish we had gone to Bobby's Burger Palace and spent our money at the tables getting drunk on watered down vodka tonics.

py_DztSMCxuTBANZlKndpQ.text: Restaurants like Sage are the reasons my husband and I keep coming back to Vegas over and over again. This is what it's about! Good food, good company, great service, great atmosphere!  This place was outstanding!  Our server and sommelier were so friendly and helpful. It always makes a restaurant experience when you get top notch service. Our sommelier was able to help us pick out an amazing wine that we would've had trouble pairing with our food otherwise.   Get a cocktail, they are well mixed and delicious.   We did the chef's tasting menu. Course after course of goodness. The whole dinner seemed to have a playful autumn and smokey theme to it. Some highlights:  -Sourdough and bacon bread with flaky salt---mmmm! I wish there were more of it. Not the epic bread carts of some other restaurant, but tasty portions to get your salivary glands pumping.  -oyster shooter amuse bouche--plus tequila. Yum!  -Shaved foie gras on a walnut gelatin concoction.   -Day boat scallop was sweet buttery goodness.  -My husband had the egg yolk with a smokey foam---probably the best dish on the menu (from the vegetarian side of things)  -Ribeye was quite possibly the most delicious piece of beef I have ever tasted. Succulent, perfectly cooked, crispy sear. Oh my goodness!  -Pear custard with root beer bubbles. A nice palette cleanser.   -Petite sundae--like a fruity pebble dance in your mouth!  Wow, what a great night!  We left fat and happy. Would come here again to try a different menu.

1fmjl7T77oo05QERAL1Tpw.text: It's been a couple weeks so I don't remember details, but I do remember having a great experience.. Amazing food and first class service. I've dined at Michelin star restaurants all over the world like Per Se, etc. and this was definitely at the top of my list of best meals.

LuEStcRUI3QDPqqp5qFG-A.text: Wow. Wow. Wow. Wow. There really aren't any words to describe how excellent Sage is. I give it six stars, how's that for wow?   I have been here twice for dinner, once during Restaurant Week when it first opened (best decision ever) and then for my husband's birthday. Both times the food and service were beyond spectacular. The restaurant interior is impeccably decorated and provides the experience of a luxurious yet inviting restaurant.   For appetizers I have tried the steak tartare and roasted pumpkin soup, both really, really good. The pear and brussel sprouts salad with red endives in a bacon mustard vinaigrette, the wagyu short rib with an interesting horseradish potato puree and the ochicken were all excellent. For dessert I have tried a fruit tart-type of thing, the pineapple mousse and gelato.   The cocktails are excellent as well. I can't recall exactly what I drank but it had pine nuts in it, VERY INTERESTING. It wa super delicious, I highly recommend it.   Sage has been, without a doubt, one of my best dining experiences I've had in this city.

pXkVTQq7_S-4bLuR0Ui7TQ.text: Great service, delicious food, nice ambiance....  When food like Sage's makes me moan with every bite,  it's a 5 star in my book.  Service was great, our waiter (wish I remembered his name) was nice and very attentive without being snooty.  I was impressed when he handed us an Ipad and a quick tutorial on how to view the drink menu on it.  Ok it takes little to impress me but still....  - Complimentary pre appetizer mango froth from the chef was light and tasty.  - Complimentary bacon bread and sourdough loaf with australian sea salt and butter- good but would have liked the bread to be warm.  - 36 hour wagyu braised short rib - flavorful, melts in your mouth short rib, heaven.    - The hubs had the $89 prix fix menu and chose the grilled oysters, Spanish octopus, Australian sirloin plus foie gras for 10 bucks extra and olive oil ice cream with hazelnut crunch and basil jam. - all amazing.  Sage is one of your pricier restaurants but hey it's Vegas, gotta splurge at least once or twice when you're here.  I wouldn't say the ambiance is super fancy but it's nice and worthy enough to get dressed up for.  I did see guys in there wearing jeans and a t-shirt, which I thought was kind of meh but just fyi if you were wondering about the attire.

HhYRqF3dSwYLMygUClx1Iw.text: Was here Friday night - half empty. Food was good but we were in a party of 8 and the service was TERRIBLE. our server showed up only when necessary and we had to wait at least 45 minutes before we could order. Pompous sommelier pushing magnum bottles. For his empty the restaurant was on a peak weekend night felt that service was nowhere near where it should have been for $300 tip we were "obligated" to pay due to having a large party size.

FDsaWbjpi92HNd--6d9oMQ.text: This place is perfection, I did the tasting menu paired with wine, every piece of protein  was cooked perfectly and the timing was spot on as we transitioned to the next meal, we had an incredibly knowledgeable waiter and when they brought the wine the explanation was better then I've received at a vineyard tasting room before. I would highly recommend this place! The flavor on every dish progressively got better as the meal went on.

8Lo2iu9Id-ovQX0K-PVRgA.text: Mediocre food and horrible service. We made reservations for 4 people but couldn't get them until 9:45pm - we arrived early and the restaurant was practically empty. Ordered the chef's tasting menu and the dessert was the highlight of the courses. The entrees were over-salted and uninspired.   Our waiter transitioned service just after we were served our 3rd course (I've never experienced this at a "fine dining" restaurant with coursed dishes - typically the waiter finishes your service before leaving). We waited over half an hour to have our empty dishes removed from our table and then another 15 for our dessert to arrive. No apologies or explanation from the wait staff for the delay. Meanwhile, the tables of 60+ year-olds around us were being waited on hand and foot and never had empty wine glasses.  Very disappointed in this dining experience. I was excited for a decent meal and expected much more. I'm willing to spend a lot for good meals, but the food and service here just don't justify the price.

UenMaR1gJIb5dYGQZ87cJw.text: This place is absolutely EXCELLENT! I came here with my boyfriend and our experience was absolutely amazing! I would highly recommend this restaurant to anybody and everybody! The GM Nathan and other manager Precious were so nice, welcoming, and accommodating! Our server was James who was knowledgeable and kind, along with his assistant Derrick who was so sweet and nice! The sommelier Nick was very knowledgeable and great with his recommendations of wine to pair with our food! This place is great and I would definitely come back!

iK2E6ne8JQOY6kS4AHTQkw.text: Best  Asian on the strip hands down. High end food with a beautiful atmosphere. Service was right on

oYyEnDjmQ95G47mRN2cj_w.text: As a Chicagoan, I'm so proud of Chef Shawn McClain and his restaurant Sage! From a huge of list of celebrated chefs and their restaurants to choose from in Vegas, Sage made it to our list of places to dine. No, regrets whatsoever. In fact, we walked out as happy and very satisfied diners.  I tried their 4-course Signature Tasting Menu and my husband went with the ala carte options. The wonderful thing about it is that the entire table doesn't have to do the tasting menu. Phew. However, if you want to do the 10-course menu then the entire table needs to also do it because of the complexity of trying to coordinate everyone's meals.  For the 4-course Signature Tasting Menu, you get to choose between options for each course. I chose the market oysters for my first course and to my surprise, I was given FIVE oysters! Woah! I love raw oysters on the shell so that was a great plus. Then I had the seared scallops which was also very good. The beef belly was the star of the tasting menu. It was so soft it literally melted in my mouth. Ended the tasting menu with profiteroles for dessert which was so good.  As for the ala carte menu which my husband went with, he had roasted sweetbreads which he was very happy about. I tried a piece and the soft texture was amazing. He had the hanger steak and it was prepared to perfection just as he requested: rare.  Service was also professional and attentive. Our server gave us a reasonable amount of time in between getting seated, ordering drinks, then food and also came to check in on us without overdoing it.  Sage is easily one of the top restaurants in Vegas.  Note to Chicagoans: I asked our server about Chef Shawn McClain and apparently he has plans to gradually close his restaurant businesses in Chicago to focus fulltime in his Las Vegas venture.

XBMaBTfnJCcT9BFUVEbI2Q.text: I had read some of the poor reviews below, and I was somewhat apprehensive about dining here.  In fact, I almost contemplated canceling my reservation, but I'm glad that I kept it as the food and service were exceptional.    We had heard that the specialty cocktails were tasty, so I ordered an Empire State...good but certainly not worth the Vegas price premium.  We did have the kumomoto oysters which featured a tabasco kick.  For our main course, we ordered the special:  Aged bone in Prime Ribeye steak for two which included the marrow.  It was sensational, and the presentation was equally good.  Throughout the meal, our waiter and the accompanying staff were extremely attentive.  I don't believe our water ever got to half full.  I would encourage those who are wavering to try Sage.  Date:  March 30th, 7pm

g9Yoz8W2OMkt814zHJCSsg.text: Once a month, a few friends and I get together to dine at a nice restaurant. Sage has been on our list for a long time. Three of us got there early and spent some time at the bar. The signature cocktails are innovative and fresh. Most of the ingredients are not your conventional elements and mixed well. Personally, I like the Moscow Mule. Served in the traditional copper mug, the blend of lime, ginger beer, and vodka hit the spot.   James, our server, was beyond amazing.   We started off with a glass of champagne. We found out that any full bottle of champagne or wine under $500 is half off. That is dangerous, because it lead to five bottles being consumed throughout dinner. It is a great deal for locals and a great way to get people to come back.   The best appetizers are the oysters with aged tequila mignonette and a Tabasco sorbet, roasted sweetbreads, and frois gras creme brulee. The wagyu beef tartare was decent. Nothing amazing or unique. The ones we could have done without were the octopus, yellowtail, and the brussel sprouts salad. The greens had too much of a bacon flavor. I never would have thought I'd be the one to say that. Normally bacon is the solution to all of life's problems. In this case, the smokiness was overbearing. Two different places have taught me that yellowtail is not to be ordered outside of sushi restaurants.   As for entrees, the veal cheeks and NY strip were melt in your mouth buttery goodness. The side of creamed potatoes were irresistible. The tile fish was not worth getting. I would suggest getting something else. Both of the pastas are impressive. The raviolis had large pieces of king crab meat on each stuffed pocket. The cavatelli had a generous amount of shaved truffles on it. The toasted pine nuts add a textural component to the dish that was complimentary. We were told that every dish was rich and heavy. By the end, I was done for. If death was at my door, I would gladly go.   Desserts are Sage's weak point. The sweet potato sundae was the best offering. Otherwise the other three desserts we ordered were forgettable. Skip dessert and just order another entree. Otherwise go to Jean Philippe Patisserie.

hkKDzJnRoMM4Kl__r_meZQ.text: Beautiful space, wonderful food....but not 5 stars.   I wanted to go somewhere nice and kind of fancy on our trip to Vegas. I posted to Talk and this was one of the suggestions from my fellow Yelpers. Thanks for the great suggestion.   We arrived a bit early for our 7:45 reservation so we could have a cocktail in the bar. I had a tea infused martini and my dining companion had a scotch. Service in the bar was good. The hostess came and got us promptly at 7:45 for our table. I appreciated how she carried our drinks for us to the table.   We were seated at a table with one side chair and one side booth on the end. It was cozy and the atmosphere very private and welcoming. We received an amuse bouche from the chef. It was a tomato and avocado treat. I loved it! We also received our choice of bread. I went with a basic bread, he had the bacon roll thing. Both were good. I liked the whipped butter served with sea salt. Perfect compliment.   For an appetizer, I ordered the poached egg with shaved truffles, dining companion had the yellow-tail sushi roll. I liked the egg, but I always forget truffles give me heartburn. The combination of truffle, egg, and potato puree really worked well together. He enjoyed his sushi.   I had the asparagus soup instead of salad, he had the beet salad. The soup was probably the best soup I've ever had. It was by far my favorite part of the meal.   My main dish was gnocchi, he had fish. The gnocchi was with cauliflower and other veggies. It was good, but a bit salty.   We typically do not order dessert, but we were on vacation, so I caved for the lime tart with fresh blueberries. It's been a long winter with not too many good fruits where I'm from, so that was the perfect end to the meal.   Everything was very good, but why not 5 stars? Here's why -  1. Although the food runners were good, our server disappeared for long periods of time.  2. There was a woman walking around trying to take and sell us a picture. This is a restaurant, not an amusement park. I found it off putting.  3. Not many wines by the glass to choose from. My dining companion and I don't like the same kind of wine, so a bottle is out of the question.   All in all, a good meal with great choices, presented beautifully. I'm glad we ate at Sage, but I'm not sure I would go back.
