Less is more with this dish, and they over did it.  No one at the table wanted to eat it, so it sat untouched for the duration of our dinner.  I HIGHLY RECOMMEND AGAINST THIS DISH.  -Fennel Ravioli w/ Lobster was a joke.  It was pasta, topped with lobster and whatever else it came with.  All of the ingredients were sort of layered and just laid on top of empty ravioli pasta.  My cousin decided to finish the dish, even though she did not like it, because we left so many dishes uneaten already.  Didn't bother with dessert.  At that point we were already pissed at how much money we threw away to this restaurant, and our server just sucked.  I believed all the hype that came with this restaurant and was extremely disappointed.  I will not go back, and will not recommend it to anyone.  I want to think I came on a bad night, too close to closing time, but the quality of the food and service is not worth the $30-50pp price mark.  Also, they shouldn't be taking tables an hour and a half prior to them closing if they are going to end up rushing you out.  I really want to come back and give this place another try, but my experience was just flat out horrible.    I did like the bread they offered, lol.

M1ZHY3N8AK7K4aAxkYNXGQ.text: Excellent dinner of caviar, foie gras, a bit of Tokay, all the obligatory 'let's spend some money' goodies.  The service is relaxed Vegas, professional, personable. The sommelier knows his stuff.  Very good dinner.

P2y2xLJlnrASlkaCedTPgA.text: I had the tasting menu here. I vomit after having the seafood. The seafood are not fresh. Compared to other fine dining restaurants at Aria, this one is the worst one at Aria.

X9-rjIjJ8p8uyrgHduB-4A.text: One of my favorite meals ever.  Right off the bat I was blown away by how beautiful the decor was.  Also, the tables are nice and far apart so you don't get bothered by loud annoying people.    Food highlights were: - the oysters, which are delicious and come perfectly dressed - the poached egg, which was shockingly good - skirt steak, which was amazingly tender and fantastically marinated.    The only disappointment for me was the foie gras candy bar, which I had super high hopes for but was underwhelming.    Another great thing about this place is the service, which is among the best I've had at any restaurant.    Definitely a must-try

lTtiPbF06PGOb-BhjC6QXA.text: Nathan and the gang serve up a meal and setting that will leave you impressed.  The veal cheeks and iberico pork are two of the best dishes you can ask for.    And a bonus for having some of the nicest and most knowledgeable bartenders on the strip.

o4N_iveQd-Fhs_tyn8khZw.text: After a lot of research, we (brother, cousin, me) chose this as our fine dining restaurant of the trip. The ambience is fantastic - dark, comfy seating, great decor.  Service was excellent. When I didn't like the drink I ordered, the server let me taste something else before pouring. Every course was explained and questions asked to the chef and answered (my brother is in culinary school and had a few questions). The timing was perfect - not too fast or slow.  The food was amazing. My brother and cousin ordered the 4 course tasting menu and I had the 6 course chef's menu. We shared each course which was perfectly prepared, presented and sized.  They have an absinthe cart that we did not sample, but it looked interesting.   I would not hesitate to recommend this restaurant or eat there again the next time I'm in Las Vegas!

_mkzqri1L4be3Ao_ikpNWQ.text: Too many options on the strip but Sage came highly recommended.   Drink:  I had the 'Elusive Spring' which is a nice, light & refreshing cocktail made with Buffalo Trace bourbon.    Eat:  The American Red Snapper (excuse the blurry pic) on a bed of peas and gnocci...I finished every morsel on my plate!  So delicious & not at all heavy.   They also start you off with some fennel amuse bouche thingy - I can't tell you what it was but it was a nice bite.  Sweet:  None for me but the mezcal float and extensive absinthe menu caught my eye  Staff:  Nice and non-intrusive service  Ambience:  Low key, sophisticated but not stuffy & good music (deep house?)

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. American Red Snapper
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Elusive Spring

jdamXflREyQNUv4tSFvyKQ.text: Restaurant Week was cut short for us this time, because I was traveling to Chicago. We snuck in one more dinner beforehand at Sage. It is also one of our favorite restaurants so we knew it would not disappoint. Sage is great on many levels, but one thing that sets it apart from others is its beer menu. They always have a great selection and a few rare choices on draft. One day, I'm determined to come hungry enough to try the tasting menu with beer pairings.   On this day, though, the husband had a German beer, Schneider Weisse, and I had St. Feuillien Saison from Belgium. Both were delicious! Already off to great start, we welcomed the choice of bacon or baguette rolls. The baguette is my favorite. And we were brought an amuse bouche of lamb tartare. Yum! What a scrumptious little bite. While we intended to both choose items from the Restaurant Week menu, the husband opted to order off the menu so he could enjoy some favorites. My three courses for $50.13 included Chilled Sweet Corn Soup, Sea Scallops and Funnel Cake. He ordered Sweetbreads ($17) and the NY Strip Steak ($54).   The soup was silky and smooth with chunks of delicate Dungeness crab. Huitlacoche was also part of this dish. It's not something I was familiar with, which is part of the fun at Sage. It always introduces me to something new. It's fungus that grows on corn, it's not common in the US, but in Mexico it is treated like a delicacy. Like we would consider truffles to be. His sweetbreads were amazing, just like the first time we had them at Sage for my birthday dinner. I was fortunate that he shared. He must love me.  His steak was beautifully prepared; a perfect medium-rare and it was piled high with mushrooms. Accompanied with a side buttery mashed potatoes. My scallops had a lovely sear and on the side was a lovely medley with sweetness from grapes, smoky saltiness from the bacon and the earthiness of the chanterelles.   We wrapped up this outstanding meal with funnel cake laced with strawberries and malted ice cream. It was a fantastic version of the carnival classic. Service was once again exceptional. They do it right at Sage. I hope it stays put for a good long time.

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. funnel cake
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. scallops
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. mashed potatoes

WgpkH3lOElptSmqQtqnmKQ.text: Sage - you will find it tucked neatly and quietly into a corner of Aria, dwarfed by other restaurants, but you need to go here to treat yourself to a delectable meal.  Ambiance - typical of Strip restaurant venue, but with a touch of old-school, almost speak-easy look with large dated paintings on the wall and antique lamp shades next to the tables. All the touches were there, including variations in plating, quirky silverware, and impeccable service by the waiter and busser.  Bread service offered a brioche roll and a cheddar-bacon roll, along with an herbed, very creamy, spreadable butter, and accompanying salt (from Australia we were told).  $89 Tasting Menu - of which my friend and I ordered off of, each ordering a different item, and we shared a majority of the food between the two of us.  Wagyu Beef Tartare: A serenade of flavors with a cracked egg on top and served with crusty bread. Salty, but savory and an obvious taste of carefully cured meat.   Foie Gras Custard Brulee: Not exactly my favorite dish of the night. Crackled top offered too much bitterness with only a hint of sweet, paired with also bitter kumquats - this dish just did not have a medley of flavors that would be expected.   Grilled Spanish Octopus: A gorgeously plated dish with served along with Chorizo aioili and a textural surprise - Marcona almonds! All in all a taste festival in your mouth.  Maine Day Boat Scallops: Nothing wrong with large succulent scallops. Bathe them in the sauce that comes in the dish, and add some of the oxtail for best flavor combination.   Bacon-Wrapped Iberico Pork Loin: Rich and almost sinfully delightful pork belly is served along with the loin, which Is nothing like you will find outside of an establishment like Sage - or perhaps Spain if you'd like to travel there to have some piggy delightfulness.  48 Hour Beef Belly: Never mind the pork belly, this beef belly was so rich I could barely finish the portion I was given. Not to say it was not good - it was definitely more than good, and combined with the sweet onion and crunchy root vegetables you can't go wrong.  Meyer-Lemon Cheesecake: Probably the least strong of everything I ate. Just too many flavors and too much going on with this dessert to truly enjoy it.  Foie Gras Candy Bar (ordered outside of the tasting menu, but only $20) - Melt in your mouth creamy peanut butter and foie awaits you encased in a chocolate milk bar, topped with a dusting of gold and crunchy popcorn. Once you cut into it, the caramel oozes out and you pretty much die and go to heaven. The end.  Just kidding, we also ended out meal with a selection of teas - I had a pomegranate that was flavorful and refreshing, and lastly we were presented with a "shot" of hot chocolate flavored with rosemary - a surisingly lovely combination of flavors.   Highly recommended. Foodie must list. I will be back.

1rF7mewD8ooAgGJwBbrgSQ.text: Came here as part of my birthday dinner.  Located within Aria, Sage is one of the higher end restaurants in the plethora of fine dining establishments in Las Vegas. The decor of this restaurant creates a more intimate, private, dining environment where lights are dimmed and the decor is very Vegas-esque in that it is grand, and clean.  The Sage menu is well-balanced with a selection of meat dishes, appetizers, and fish. If you are coming from CA like me, there are some foie gras dishes you may partake in ordering. As we had a long night ahead of us, and loved the selections on the 4 course meal, we both settled for that.   Course #1: Beef tartare: This was the BEST beef tartare I've ever had. Hands down, delicious including the warm, crunchy, bread it was served with. If you enjoy a good beef tartare, this is a must. I also tried some of my girlfriend's foie gras creme brulee, which in my opinion was too sweet and funny tasting for my liking.   Course #2: Maine Scallops: The scallops weren't the best I've had but the overall dish was good. All-in-all, a decent dish.  Course #3: Australian Wagyu Sirloin: A fancy name for a dish that basically boils down to just being sirloin cuts serves with a fioe gras with creamy potatoes. The beef itself had great flavor and tenderness to it (cooked just how I asked), however I was a little put off by the foie gras. It mixed in with my potatoes and didn't taste like a great combo. I tried the 48-hour beef belly which although flavorful, felt a bit dry (overcooked).  Course #4: We finished off our meal with the Milk Chocolate Cremeux. Normally, I don't enjoy sweets but this one was delicious. The Milk chocolate was extremely rich and came with a small scoop of ice cream to help blend the taste. We also had a Nut cake with caramel shavings which, when eaten together, had great flavors but wasn't all there texture wise.  Service here was good, but I felt it could have definitely been better. The pace of the meal though we both went with the 4 course meal was slow, and we were sitting in between each course. Admittedly, the service and pace account for the lost star. The meal all in all was pretty expensive and given its price and the different caliber of restaurants I've eaten at for that price, it probably wasn't worth it, but then again it is Vegas and I still enjoyed my birthday.

40ebQDXJM5IpbzgU_uk9jA.text: Very very nice place. Went here with a group for one of my friends birthdays and was pleasantly surprised. Very upscale, but the food was spectacular. You get what you pay for and this place is an example of that. Superb wine list with some really good wines. We definitely had a positive experience! Have to try the bacon Parmesan raviolis! To die for!

us7lbPjG0aQCM3eCGztO2g.text: The merlot that they offer on their wine menu is very good and worth the $15/glass.  As for the quality and value of their NY strip steak and Yellow-tail appetizer, I gave this place 2 stars (experienced much better).  Where this restaurant shines is in their sauces.  I found the dishes flavorful but the dishes lacked proper execution. The NY strip steak ($54) that I ordered was well seasoned from the bone marrow but was served lukewarm and it was not seared enough to give it that nice charred flavor and texture. And the la ratte potato had the texture of thick glue/paste - which made it unappetizing for me.   As for the yellow-tail appetizer ($22), it was thinly sliced and there were maybe only 2 ounce of fish (see pic).  One word to describe this dish would be - overpriced!!  If you are going to charge more for your food, at least train your staff to provide better service.  With so many better quality and value and excellent service restaurants in Las Vegas, I would not return nor recommend this restaurant to anyone.    Self parking and complimentary valet services available.

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Yellow-tail sashimi appetizer is overpriced for what you get.
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. NY Strip - was average.

rViPA2KTQotyNljxI8XV2g.text: Very elegant and trendy ! Loves the foie gras brulee and the scallops .  Very sexy date spot !

Tu0qvqc49ZekmXoVnEKlzg.text: The short version:  Sage was good, just not spectacular.   Vegetarians will be challenged to find enough to eat and even more challenged to find something worth the $100 (per person) meal tab....  The long version:  We had a party of 8 for a family member's 50th birthday party.  We were staying in the Aria so this was a big deal for us.  I called a couple of days ahead to confirm that they could accommodate the birthday boy: a vegetarian.  I was told "no problem" essentially.  in fact they said that he could ask for anything he wanted and the chef would make it if they had the ingredients in the kitchen.  This sounded great, so we went with Sage for our party.  Flash forward to the birthday celebration and when I arrived, I spoke to the hostess to remind them what they'd told me, that the birthday honoree would be asking for something off the menu.  Suddenly they changed their tune - we can't just make him anything....  This wasn't really what I'd hoped for for the vegetarian guest of honor of an 8-person meal that would likely cost over $1,000.  Sage had little on the menu that was vegetarian friendly and it wasn't what was described when I booked the party.  Anyway, everyone ordered some kind of starter or salad and an entree.  I asked our server if their asparagus salad had any greens on it, was it an actual "salad."  She said 'no' it was just asparagus and egg.  Since there wasn't any kind of "salad" starter, I asked for a mixed green salad, same as the birthday boy was getting.  It was wholly uninspired.  Just one type of baby lettuce tossed with a vinaigrette.  And to my disappointment I saw someone else getting the asparagus salad and turns out it *was* a salad with greens - arugula I believe.  Our server wasn't completely familiar with the menu apparently...  Next was the "amuse bouche" which is cool that they brought it out.  However, the 3 vegetarians at our table got a scrap of blood orange with a sprig of fennel on it.  Essentially it was a stripped down version of what the meat eaters got.  But frankly, again, for a $1,000 meal this seemed like a lame compromise/accommodation.  What kind of mouth amusement was a scrap of orange with a pinch of fennel? I was starting to see a trend here.  I don't think Sage's chef or staff really respect vegetarians.  Sure, they'll accommodate them, but it's a lackluster accommodation - uninspired, perhaps almost begrudging.  I will say our meals, those who weren't eating vegetarian were very good.  The honoree, the vegetarian, got the crab ravioli without the crab, which was basically 1 of only 2 options available to him and suggested by our server as the better choice.   But guess what?  He got a few ravioli in a bowl - 5 maybe, and they were EMPTY.  Just 5 little squares of pasta in a cream sauce.  What kind of entree is that?  Nothing else substantial was added to the plate to bulk it up for him.  So, for his meal, a man at his 50th birthday party, the best Sage could do was give him a plate of plain lettuce tossed in vinagrette and 5 EMPTY ravioli in a cream sauce.  The guest of honor was treated like an afterthought, a second class citizen.  It's clear Sage is biased against vegetarian diners and makes little effort to give them exciting options.  That'd be OK if it weren't for the fact that I called ahead of time and was told otherwise.    So, bottom line, vegetarians are better off skipping Sage.  For the rest of you, I'd say Sage is good but not THAT good.  As far as the atmosphere - much hoopla on the web about how cool the restaurant is and how great the ambiance is.  It's just a lot of hype.  Sage is a basic rectangular room with some curtains and mirrored type gold against the walls and not much more.  Some sampled blow up French impressionistic artwork graces small portions of the restaurant but it actually gives it a cheap feel, not a fancy one.  The decor is tame and uninspired.  To call it "Minimalist" would be kind.  Not much atmosphere to speak of except slightly dimmed lights.

G2CKrLhxWbfgVTD8G7F94w.text: For a birthday in Las Vegas, we decided to try out something new, the Sage restaurant in Aria Hotel. We're glad we did!  First, Sage is a beautiful space filled with beautiful people. Mostly 20-somethings and 30-somethings in the bar, which was hopping by 8:00pm. The restaurant is all dark and elegant.   The food is mostly deserving of its Zagat rating and local praise. The highlights were: braised beef short rib, which had a marvelous demi glace and garnished with roasted parsnips and carrots. Delicious! The scallops were enormous and wonderful.  Less successful was the duck breast, which was chewy. And the fish of the night was unspectacular. You do better with meats here.  Desserts are good, but get ready for tiny portions. Apple fritters were very small fritter bits scattered with a small amount of apple. The purple sweet potatoe pie with charred marshmallow was delicious, but again, the tiny wedge of pie could fit in a toddler's hand. For $12-15, you'd think you were getting desserts that are sharable!  As others have mentioned, service was erratic. Our waiter was professional enough, but he seemed to have too many tables, even some very far away -- why not delegate sections for waiters? Even with different assistant waiters and water boys, we still had to wait quite a bit. We ordered absinthe with our desserts, and it was completely forgotten. Then we had to ask to have it removed from the bill. Little things like that take away from the experience.

m-6sreqAsNES4RnXonRIRw.text: This place is supposed to one of the best Restaurants @ the Aria & they close @ 10:30pm on a Saturday Night ?!!  No Bueno lol even though their Yelp says they open until 11pm but they actual close even earlier.... Ummmm everything else was Really Busy, Sage you disappointed us... Oh well @ least there's other good Options around ;)

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bartender made a Drink Specially for Muahhhh ;)

gLWDFIlrt83RsiufijN68A.text: Food is obviously great here. I had a steak, it was perfect. The service was impeccable.  The staff does a really great job here, I would definitely give them 5 stars.   I guess some people enjoy these kind of cold, pretentious places. It's just really not my style. I'm not sure it's actually anyone's style, I think people just like to pretend to be so refined.   But yes I would recommend Sage for the great food and excellent service. The atmosphere could use a little more life and energy.

v0p8j-2O1Ehii1q8W2_sbQ.text: I surely do not understand how this could only be listed as four stars!?!  I don't have any idea how they can cook his well. I was with my wonderful daughter who is in town for a convention, so I didn't want to waste a minute of talking with her - otherwise I would have written this review last night while I had the The names of everything, and could have taken pictures. I'll have to read the other reviews to see why people didn't give it five stars. I certainly do!

Sdal_r3x_zCqOuklTHtHfg.text: My wife and I had a couple of drinks and appetizers at Sage last week, and the experience was absolutely amazing!  Since we were there without child, we decided to go on a culinary adventure and, instead of dining at one restaurant, we opted to get a couple of dishes at 3 restaurants.   It certainly isn't a good way to go as far as cost since it's a much more expensive endeavor, but seeing as I luckily won $1300 the night before, I didn't really give a damn about the cost.  We started our dining experience at Sage, where we sat at the bar.   Aaron Baca, the bartender or mixologist if you prefer, guided us through the menu and made a couple of spectacular Woodford Reserve Manhattans for my wife.   We opted to go with the oysters first and Mr. Baca highly recommended the Foie Gras Creme Brulee.  Oh. My. God.   Both my wife and I were speechless.   The Creme Brulee was simply fucking divine.   Pure ambrosia, there's no other way to say it.     If you're in Vegas and are looking for a good place to eat, you simply must try Sage.   Service and food are both impeccable.

JoD1eIa-f5CuLHp-fpwRmQ.text: Another visit at Sage in my last Vegas trip.   This time we just ordered from their regular menu. I tried their Foie Gras Creme Brulee served with salted brioche, entered the second course with Veal Cheeks with Candied Carrots and Creamy Polenta, ended the meal with Coconut Key Lime Float.  They changed the bar menu to iPads for easier surfing, you can see the actual image of the drinks without having to search through tons of pages of pictures on Yelp. Another great experience here beginning with our server who's named Bond. Such a humorous guy who told us he's a secret agent (whoops, not so secretive anymore!)  Anyway, finally tried their famous Foie Gras Creme Brulee. It's a very rich starter, slightly offset by the strawberry jam dabbed in the center, scoop a spoonful onto the fluffy brioche, and what you have there is a mouthgasm. Basically you have a little bit of everything, savory fragrant foie gras, salty and buttery brioche, and a tad tarty sweet balance. I must say, I should have ordered a lighter entree because it was quite a heavy appetizer.   Next came my mini pot of veal cheeks. Veal cheeks were made correctly, very soft and tender in each bite. Fatty pieces? Why of course! That's the best part of tender meat. I am not the biggest carrot fan nor sweets, I must admit that I was picking at the carrots. They served their part flavoring the sauce and making the polenta less bland. It might be just me, but I could barely finish half of this plate after the foie gras brulee. A bit too much flavors going on that made this dish less appealing, mistake on my part.  And then entered my funny server. He handed the menu to me saying that he knows exactly what I want. Unfortunately points at another heavy piece of dessert, Gianduja Pave. I could handle it a year ago, but not this time, I opted for the Coconut Key Lime Float, something to cleanse my palette and something light. Not a disappointment at all! when my dessert came, I was like "oh cool, a sorbet in a glass cup set on top of a bowl of ice. NBD" Then comes the fun part, like the experiment of dry ice. The foam for the float was a tequila based soda. It looked like I had a white volcano for dessert. I had the next table wanting to take pictures of my dessert. And if you want to order this, be sure to have your camera ready, the foam sinks in so quickly, your newest phone might not load fast enough for it. As expected, very light in the tequila taste, each scoop of gelato has very well defined flavors. I wouldn't suggest eating either of it alone. Maybe you can for the coconut, but the lime is darn tarty by itself!

Ev92KYqbNs7vLR1JfftXiQ.text: Wow !!!! For the first time in my life I will review this as the most amazing dinner I have ever had, I was actually excited with every dish that came out, I had chestnut soup that was absolutely delicious, and their fish is incredible!! Even their Arnold planer was done with real lemons and was the best I have ever had   GO !!! MUST GO   5+ stars

06Aels7q_-WCaNM8MQW4TA.text: Beautiful restaurant, great food, and company make a memorable experience. The interior of Sage has ageless attention to detail. Reservations are always hard to get when you're in town and if it's last minute at some of the fancier restaurants. It was a Sunday and didn't find trouble dining here but it later in the evening that worked with our schedule.  The drink menu at Sage is quite extensive with a great selection of absinthe and high end spirits. We ordered a few drinks. I don't recall exact names but each had high quality ingredients. Our party all ordered from the chef's 4 course tasting menu and was shared from each other. The waiter brought out warm rolls with an herb butter. To our surprise, the waiter brought out a spoonful of tuna tartare from the chef for our tasting which was quite good. From the chef's signature menu, we ordered wagyu beef tartare, foie gras custard brulee, grilled baby octopus, main day boat scallops, 48 hr beef belly, Snake River Farms flat iron, bacon wrapped Iberico pork loin.  Every dish was superb.  For dessert, we chose the milk chocolate and early grey panna cotta with madeleines, blackberry scalded milk gelato and ricotta cheesecake with smoked graham crumbs white chocolate pearls and blueberry basil gel. These desserts were good and different. Honestly, a bit too complicated for me. I'd rather same something simple.  Aside from the food, the service was great. As mentioned, we had a later reservation and we were there way past closing time along with two other parties and the staff was still accommodating.

hKtTgDojYAyoflGM4jL89Q.text: Mediterranean cuisine at the Aria.  Beautiful dining room with impeccable service. Nice glass of Sancerre, steak tartar and black bass.

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States

QCs4xV8HU2y0Htd3hGKSxw.text: Really exceptional food and ambiance, but the service is horrid. We had show reservations and made the restaurant reservations two months prior and they were 40 minutes late on seating our party. Then the waiter was throwing lots of shade and being extremely slow which made us almost miss our show . I was only able to get one round of drinks, they never came around again. They we slow in clearing dishes which made subsequent course delivery difficult.    I do not recommend this restaurant.

cju1nOVuntfpVTnzGV2L3g.text: Came here for dinner and we were not disappointed. There was a short wait, maybe 15 minutes despite having reservations but the bar staff are friendly and it was entertaining to watch them concoct the fancy drinks. Food was outstanding!  The veal cheeks were like butter. Service is outstanding and the waiter even went to ask the chef what one ingredient was in my meal that I loved but could not place (dehydrated sauerkraut, who knew?). Ambience is lovely, not too dark not too bright and reasonably quiet at least when we were there. We would absolutely return. Reservations HIGHLY recommended especially during a busy season or if there is a big convention in town.

bZ3VcDoBHsflIgk7Hp8pAQ.text: Wonderful dinner! My favorite cocktail in Vegas so far- Gin and cucumber- so refreshing and not sweet! We had the scallops and they were totally Amazing!! The waiter asked if we had any time constraints when we sat down and yes we had a show to get to. And he totally made it work of us! Very impressed and look forward to eating here again!

DlVH7HNy8rhYFtMy006uRQ.text: This review is long overdue, but it's here! I went here with my boyfriend and my friend for her birthday. She ordered the tasting menu with her choices of the scallops, sirloin, and I forgot what dessert she got. I ordered the foie gras creme brulee and beef tartare for an appetizer. I can't forget how amazing the foie gras tasted. I love foie gras and creme brulee, I would've never imagined how perfect a marriage between them would be. The salted brioche that it came with was soft with a slight crunch. I definitely had to ask for extras. The beef tartare was super refreshing. My boyfriend loved this one and ate most of it haha.   For the main course I ordered the rabbit and my boyfriend had the Kobe Skirt. I ordered the rabbit because I never had it before and I was just like, "okay I'll try it!" The rabbit dish was super interesting because they cooked it in three different ways. Eating the three different textures of the meat was a new experience. I loved the fried one the most because it was crunchy on the outside and soft in the inside. The flavor was amazing and everything was cooked perfectly . I was lucky enough to take a bite of the Kobe skirt steak that my boyfriend ordered, and that was also very delicious!   For dessert I had the banana cake. The presentation was beautiful. They also gave us a small complimentary dessert after which was lavender milk. That was tasty, I loved it.

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bread
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Foie gras brulee with brioche
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States

xhff-e9K3eoAxBF3BCgOwA.text: We've stayed at the Aria numerous times, but this was the first time we tried Sage. It was our anniversary weekend so we decided to splurge a bit and take a chance on this restaurant. Perhaps it was also that model on the "Aria channel" subliminally telling us about James Beard award winning chef Shawn McClain over and over again too..  Cocktails-wise, I totally spaced that Sage has a wide array of absinthes. We enjoyed a couple of Old Fashioneds and a Smoking Bulleit - both bourbon fare. Big surprise on our part since we always default back to whiskey and bourbon. These drinks were done really well!   I could not decide what to eat since a lot of the menu sounded good. I went with the $89 tasting menu from which I chose:  Fois Gras Custard Brulee served with a salted brioche - a desert like fois gras mix of sweet and salty with a custard texture but crispy Creme brulee top. Sensory overload of satisfying goodness!  Maine Day Boat Scallops - the braised oxtail with salted caramel reduction and wild mushrooms dressed these scallops to the nines. Scallops are scallops - typical everyone's reliable favorite but the sauce and wild shrooms with oxtail made them stand out  Snake River Farms Flat Iron - cooked to perfection and bathed in red wine Bernaise sauce and the creamy potato puree was an excellent side kick  Dark Chocolate Panna Cotta with Red Velvet Sponge Cake - I'm not typically a dark chocolate fan but this was ridiculously good. I am reluctant to say so because of course dark chocolate is typically rich and amazing to everyone but this dessert capped the end to the tasting menu with flawless disregard. Yes, the sponge cake was velvety and airy!   My hubby ordered: Waygu Beef Tartare - with crispy chocolate, slow poached egg and crushed capers - this appetizer killed the flavor senses. The taste buds were given no mercy. Loved this!  Braised Veal Cheeks - tender, succulent, rich!  Service? As expected, our waiter and his accompanying staff were consistently helpful even though they were super busy Friday night but not over bearing. We were really pleased with our overall experience. The atmosphere was lively and the music was a slow but progressive electronic pulse that kept an energetic setting for the contemporary American dishes set before us.

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dark Chocolate Panna Cota
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Braised veal cheeks
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Snake River Farms Flat Iron Steak in Red Wine Bernaise

QWdx5Prkk3hiuox9gGMyMQ.text: Had the tasting menu 2/23/19. Overall good but the lamb chop was only ok (way too much fat). Nice mixtures of foam / purees / sauces and textures. Dessert was the standout. Did not do wine pairings. Extensive wine list with standard Vegas mark-up. Sommelier was very helpful and he was up to the challenges we posed him (10 people with varying levels of wine snobbery). Would recommend the Paul Hobbs Pinot / Frank Family Cabernet / Tamber Bey Cabernet. Suggest sitting in main dining room if going for romantic dinner.

TGu3tParAL3qm5ixSZs_nA.text: Sage is located in the Aria Hotel. The ambiance is elegant with dim lights, high ceilings, purple lighting, and catchy music playing in the background. Each table has a black vase centerpiece with yellow tulips. The color theme of the restaurant is gold, black, and purple. ::Drinks:: I got the Pink Cashmere from the Sage Signature Cocktails Menu. It has Grey Goose Cherry Noir, White Cranberry Juice, Lime Juice, and Cotton Candy. This drink is so cute and fun. First I got a martini glass filled with pink cotton candy. Then the contents of martini shaker were slowly poured over the cotton candy. I watched the cotton candy disappear and turned into my drink. I posted a video on it if you want to see it in action. (yelp.com/user_local_phot...) ::Food:: We got french rolls with butter and green onions, I think. It also came with Pink Australian Sea Salt, it went well with the butter. The bread was warm but over toasted. Then we each got tuna tartare amuse bouche which was served on a tasting spoon. I liked it, the portion was perfect. I got the Chef Mcclain's Signature Tasting Menu which it includes four courses. For each course, you choose which dish you want. For the First Course, I got the Foie Gras Custard Brulee. It also came with a warm and buttery roll. I never had this dish before, it was rich and creamy. The second Course is the Grilled Spanish Octopus. It had a lot of different flavors mixed together; I liked it. Next one is the Third Course. I choose the 48 Hour Beef Belly. It was tender and had the smoked flavor. (yelp.com/user_local_phot...) (yelp.com/user_local_phot...) (yelp.com/user_local_phot...) (yelp.com/user_local_phot...) ::Dessert:: The Fourth Course is the dessert. I got the Ricotta Cheesecake that came with graham crumbs, white chocolate, blueberries and basil gel. It was smooth, creamy, and slightly tart. I also tasted the Milk Chocolate and Earl Grey Panna Cotta which I liked better than the Ricotta Cheesecake. (yelp.com/user_local_phot...) (yelp.com/user_local_phot...) ::Rating:: My friends also got the Tasting Menu but some of us ordered different dishes and I got to taste them. The top dishes I really enjoyed are, Grilled Spanish Octopus, Maine Day Boat Scallops, Snake River Farms Flat Iron, and the Milk Chocolate and Earl Grey Panna Cotta. ::Customer Service:: Excellent! Everyone was very polite and catered to us. ::Tip:: Call for reservations ::M's Notes:: -Inside Seating -Bar Area -Parking Garage

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Grilled Spanish Octopus
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Maine Day Boat Scallops
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 48 Hour Beef Belly

giEUOjZDewV0otBDgzEyNA.text: Great spot located in Aria. Beautiful atmosphere, friendly faces and great food make for an awesome evening.    I read from other reviews that reservations are hard to get but I had no problem and the place was not overly crowded.   Upon entering you walk through a large bar area into the main dining area.    The wine menu was large and should be able to accommodate anyone's taste.   I had the wagyu beef tartar with a poached egg and chocolate for an appetizer.  It was great.  A great combination of flavors.    I had the wagyu beef short rib for my dinner.  It was great, just great.  My complaint was the potato swirl that accompanied it.  It was rock hard like it had been reheated 5 times and passed from plate to plate.   Come on, you can make an incredible meal but pay no attention to the potato.  Leave it off the plate for that matter. I could have thrown it at a mirror and broke the mirror.   For dessert I had the dark chocolate panna cotta. Very good.    Overall it was a great experience with super friendly service and smiles.  I loved the atmosphere. I would recommend it to friends.   P.S.  For the love of God, do something about that stupid potato.

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Wagyu beef tartare with a poached egg on top.
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef short rib.

8MbgMCfmj1oSO6tQkyGQMg.text: Sage restaurant is located within close proximity of the check-in at the Aria Resort and Casino lobby level. Due to the volume of high quality 4 to 5-star restaurants at the Aria, this restaurant could be overlooked once you check in to your room at the hotel as it is situated in the hotel lobby, and not alongside the other restaurants on the casino floor or the second level of restaurant row. I did not notice this place until we were looking for a place to hang out for late night cocktails the same night several of us were also flying out! Sage is located next to the Lobby Bar tucked away in the corner. There are ample parking at the Aria hotel parking lot by either valet or self-park.  From the moment you are fronting this restaurant, just standing there, peeking inside, you already know this is a beautiful, classy, upscale and elegant restaurant! I believe most or all of the men were wearing coats/jackets! Luckily for me, I never entertain in Vegas without a jacket! An added emphasis as you enter the restaurant are those three pillars of glass as high as the ceiling which houses a nice selection of wine to compliment your dining pleasure!  Although we were there for only cocktails (we had dinner earlier in the evening elsewhere), I would have loved to take a peek at the menu! Just the ambiance and vibe of the place gives you the relaxed feel of a high class restaurant! With the exception of the bar area, most of Sage is dimly lit or candle lit, which gives you a more intimate and/or romantic setting if you are hanging out with that special someone!   I will definitely make a return visit to Sage, but the next time it will be to experience dinner! I am already looking forward to my next Vegas trip, and I am already looking to update this review with a complete, full review! :)

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Restaurant entry
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sage is a beautiful restaurant! Elegant, sophisticated, classy!

0zs-M9UqVxJiCyXorHWUQw.text: This is a great place to eat if you have time for a lengthy dinner and a great atmosphere.  I had the chef's vegan tasting menu and it was stellar!  Surprisingly, the pea soup was the absolute best course on the menu. The eggplant was extremely over cooked and mushy, but the flavor made up for the bad timing of the dish.  There was a mix up with the last course, but the restaurants manager kept us informed and took care of that part of the bill.  The service is wonderful and it's just a great place to splurge for dinner.

VdMvULBgoG3SFXI8u_R4Iw.text: We were SO NOT impressed with this restaurant, NOT at all! It wasn't bad, but for an upscale restaurant at Aria, it was just NOT good enough!   Beautiful restaurant for sure, it was nearly empty on a Saturday night, not a good sign. Got seated at a comfy and intimate booth, very romantic indeed. Brought our own Perrier Nuit Blanche, corkage was $35 too. Took a moment to look through the menu, our server introduced the chef's tasting menu, but I don't eat meat so we can't order that. They have vegetarian and vegan tasting menus too.   Starters: Garlic soup with prawn, the best dish of the entire meal, very nice garlic flavor, not too light or too strong, tender and fresh prawn, so good!   Dozen of Vancouver island Kushi oysters: fairly fresh, the housemade sauce was a little bland, had to ask for tabasco, tasted better with hot sauce though.   Romaine greens with parmesan cheese, my salad never came, so I asked to pack it to go, but didn't eat it when we got back, so it was a waste because they forgot about my salad.   Entrees: American kobe skirt steak in rare plus: it was not rare enough for hubby, he liked the flavors alright, was not mind blowing at all.   Pacific red snapper with veggie stock: server said this was a popular dish, OK... The fish was completely flavorless, the veggies in it were a little too raw for my taste, it tasted like grass to me, or was it the veggie broth? But the fish was very fresh and tender, just extremely bland! This dish FAILED!   We weren't interested in our entrees, didn't want desserts either, just asked them to pack everything, including our unfinished Champagne, I have to say that I had high expectations for this restaurant because of the high ratings on yelp, and the major advertisement of fine dining at Aria hotel. It was a HUGE disappointment!   The service didn't meet my expectation either, our server wasn't attentive or friendly enough, there were a few staffs served us, they all looked dull to me for some reason, or probably we finished our meal too fast that they didn't have time to check on us.    I don't think we will ever be back for Sage, this restaurant didn't work for us, just one of those high yelp rating restaurants fell short I guess, it happens sometime.  THE worst dining experience in Vegas!

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bacon bread
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Skirt steak
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Red snapper

30ZkEUUT3gZa6dhmB0I0OQ.text: Amazing experience, great service well prepared food. excelent experience. Be carefull with FIRE & ICE.

Dx9zfWUJxWOSCU7IPv6xxA.text: Dont get me wrong, i love seeing my man in a nice suit and being treated like a princess. But sometimes fine dining servers just take it a little too seriously. I mean just because we're all dressed up and dropping some big faces on foam soup and mushroom dust doesn't mean we can't crack a smile, does it?! We're in Vegas people!!! I plan on drinking wayyy too much and spending a mortgage worth on a purse at Crystals when I'm done TYSM. ; )   The restaurant itself is gorgeous. It has a nice, sexy vibe. The music is perfect and the lighting is just right. Cocktails were hand crafted by the bar and amazing. Aria has some of the best "made for you on the fly" cocktails anywhere.   I've read other reviewers talking about the pricing, I don't know about you but I can rack up a $200 bill at Cheesecake factory real quick..but usually with restaurants like these you get quality drinks so you need less and decadent, rich food that you can hardly eat a whole dish. Although the plates are typical fine dining saucers...either way the food was legit. Pretty complex flavors, very inventive dishes. Definite fine dining farm to table concept. But some of these dishes just arent my thing. I hate fois gras. Shoot me! The pork dish was one of the best parts and I enjoyed my night for sure. However I think if the bartenders could make some of the servers the drinks they made me, we would all have had a better time.

DuZv52_u-bhoz2FCvcASjg.text: We were really looking forward to dinner on our last night in Vegas. The ambiance was nice. The food was just okay.  Three meals, filet, cod and flat iron steak.  No complaints on the filet. Cod was good but the rest of the entree was flavorless. The flat iron steak was ordered medium well and came out red and was medium to medium rare. It was sent back and returned with half medium well and the other half medium and red. The steak was served sliced so not like the middle needed to be a problem and was visibly undercooked.  I ate half in lieu of sending back a third time and being the only one eating while the others were finished. I mentioned to the server, showing him the remainder on the plate and he stated it is difficult to get a steak cooked at the right temperature all the way through. I have been ordering med well for the better of 30 years.   I specifically ordered the flat iron as opposed to the filet due to difficulty in cooking med well. I know chefs do not like to "overcook" steak but I am the one paying for it and eating it.  I mean I am not at outback-a $50 steak should be better than subpar.  Skipped dessert as the selections were not appealing.  Don't waste your time here and spend your money at Andrea's, Nobu or Michael's Gourmet Room.

20GOHwCdU4GeR2TBXh15RQ.text: I love the beef tartare here!!!! been coming back many times for the beef tartare, very good service and the atmosphere is amazing!!!!  The bread is good and my latest visit I tried filet and was very good

gVZdSXPbfQcsWkp5uqpnlw.text: My best friend decided to book this restaurant for her birthday dinner. As we walked in we were greeted by our waiter and were seated. We were given menus l, as we were looking and chatting about the menu our waiter comes with complementary soups from the chef! I wanted a white wine that complemented my dinner option. The waiter went in depth when talking about wine and food choice. He even brought me with white wines to try. The food came out fast and hot with no problems.   We were allowed to enjoy our food with out the waiter coming by a million times to ask us if we are enjoying ourselves. When we were finish eating we had time to chat and laugh before my best friend was given a complementary birthday dessert.   The service was great and the food was the same. We will be coming back.

RXi1JG7r2EHMhHfI51UiHw.text: Big dollars (yay for expense budgets!), big taste!  Loved the ambience and service. Short rib special and some delicious French wines, loved so many of the plates that came our way.  If you're looking for a place to impress your date or your client this won't disappoint.

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Scallops

RMIDqfl_homETMgBM4Fw0A.text: Ugh. Went here for NYE. High expectations with such a high price tag.  When we arrived, they told us we had to wait even though it was the exact time of our reservation. Already feeling a little aggravated,  we went to the bar.  Paid 96 dollars for 4 drinks! Got seated. Waited a long time for waiter to come with menus,  even though it was a fixed price tasting menu.  Got free champagne. First course was caviar with lobster essence.  Very salty.  Second course was crab. A lot going on.  Too many flavors. Third course,  foie gras with salted brioche. Meh. Then the long wait...30 minutes until the 4th course arrived.  Risotto was ok.  Pumpkin seeds were an afterthought.  Bland. Mushy. Fifth course... scallops.  So salty that no one could finish the dish.  So so so bad. At this point, we have been in the restaurant for over 2 hours and are afraid of missing the fireworks on the strip.  Asked for our last 2 dishes to go.  Waiter looked perplexed.  Manager comped us one person's price,  which was nice.  People all over the restaurant were leaving early after having similar experiences. Really wish it would have gone differently.

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beautiful plating of second course.

-mVz-uAOifhhOfoxBo0C0Q.text: Classy restaurant for an intimate dinner or drinks. So happy we checked it out while staying at the Aria but we will also make a return trip is staying elsewhere.easy to find close to the front lobby but private and quiet inside. Loved the vibe.  Our amazing bartender showed us the ropes for enjoying Absinthe and they have the largest selection on the Strip plus many more unique choices.

wsWaL51EO_ozGDLz57Rujw.text: Exceeded expectations! New favorite spot.   I work on the strip and am responsible for making reservations for guests. My colleagues have always recommended Sage, but I hadn't been myself. I was seriously missing out!  Sage blew me away, from the friendly and welcoming hostesses, to the live classical covers of classic rock songs, to our AMAZING server, John. John inquired about any food allergies, which was wonderful because my cousin does have an allergy. He was extremely familiar with each dish and was able to keep up with my extremely inquisitive family. He made great recommendations, the pork was unreal and I order the scallops which were prepared perfectly.   Their menu is small, compared to other places, but I didn't feel like it was lacking in any regard.   The cocktail list is comprehensive and truly well-crafted. It guides you in choosing the right beverage that compliments you meal, which was a great touch. If you want to treat yourself to a very unique experience, order "The Flask".   Thank you, John for providing my family with one of our best dining experiences. The thing is, you can dine at a great restaurant, spend a few hundred dollars and feel like it wasn't worth it because of poor service... John absolutely emulated what it means to be a server at a fine dining establishment.   Thank you for all you do. It makes all of the difference when an employee seems to love their job.  Also- thank you for chasing me down and hand delivering my purse which I so carelessly forgot. (Three glasses of wine has that affect on me).  Caroline

Md1Gq0_JEkBx4i8j_odrQg.text: Absolute gem of a restaurant. Located in the Aria, hands down one of the best dining experiences i've had in las vegas, they had a Prix Fixe menu (3 courses) as well as another full menu filled with seasonal options! we decided to opt out of Prix Fixe and went for the menu which ended up costing about the same and we got to lin point items we really wanted on the menu.   Would recommend Sage to anyone. I believe it was $190 for 2 people to have 2 appetizers 2 entrees and we each had a beverage (wine and a beer)

zOTn5n1Z1UNd_vbP7N6vuw.text: Another perfect dinner at Sage. First off thanks to manager Jason, waitstaff John, bartender Aaron and all the others involved with our dinner last night. We've eaten our way around Vegas over the years and Sage stands out as the best of the best by all measures. The wife and I discussed it and decided one word- "Sophisticated", best encapsulates the experience there. The service, ambiance, drinks, and food...all sophisticated. And we love that. Please don't change! Looking forward to our next visit. Now to deal with this absinthe hangover. Thanks Chef Shawn for imagining and making such a place happen.

AtyweWaAbkHT4aGkW_YFhw.text: I checked in but forgot to leave a review  I was there eating with a group of friends before a nightclub I didn't even look at the menu! My friends ordered about 8 dishes.  We shared We ran into the guy from Entourage  Don't ask me what we ordered  What we ate.  I just drank and picked   But the service was good.  Valet was easy and location on strip was great. Table was presented great with fresh flowers for us

k0Tbv3DD-ZwDT_TE3E1dlQ.text: This review may be a little different than most. A few years ago I won an insane live auction item at a local Las Vegas charity - dinner for 20 people, in home, with Chef Shawn McClain.    The night of the event, after some preparation with then restaurant manager Robert Nikodem, 8 people from the Sage team ascended on our home and created an evening that we would never forget. Among the team was Chef Richard Camarota.   Besides the food, service, presentation, and absolute surealness of what was going on in my home, one thing that stuck with me was how family oriented the entire team was with their interactions. They held regard for each other. They were down to Earth, genuine people, despite Chef McClain's celebrity and accolades.   That's the set up to my review of finally getting to dine at Sage April 18, 2018 - over two years after the magical evening at my home with Chef McClain, Chef Camarota, Robert and the rest of the team.   I had some dear friends in town. They come to Vegas fairly regularly. We were planning to go to dinner and ran into the conundrum... there are literally hundreds of excellent, unique, remarkable restaurants on the resort corridor... how do you pick???   I used the opportunity to recommend Sage and my friends happily agreed. The cool part was I texted Chef Richard to let him know we were going so I could say hello if he was on property. He was so gracious. He replied he was out of town but would let his team know we were coming. I didn't expect anything more to be honest.   Once again - the Sage team created an unforgettable evening. Part of it, admittedly, was deliberate in that they sent out amuse-bouche and Gerard Bertrand Cremant De Limoux Rose as compliments. The rest of though was a statement of this venues excellence in every category.   Let's start with service. If you find yourself at Sage, you would be well advised to request to sit in Virginia's section. She was elegant offering the perfect amount of presence through the duration of the evening. Virginia explained the menu and advocated appropriate starters, entrees and deserts.   The atmosphere was gorgeous. The music was present but not overbearing.   I really don't want, or need, to comment on the specific food options because this review is long enough and others on here have done so in much more detail. I will say I ordered the scallops as my entree and they were perfect. No other way to describe them.   What I would like to end with was a final observation.   As we prepared to leave Virginia made a comment that stuck with me. In our saying goodbye's and thank you's, Virginia said, "if you talk to Richard please tell him we miss having him here."   Virginia didn't have to say that. But she did.   I mention that because, with the hundreds of excellent dining options in Las Vegas that you just can't go wrong with, if you want to choose a venue that is family oriented, where the people in the organization matter, and they express a regard for one another both up and down the hierarchy... then Sage is a one of a kind!   I hope you enjoy!

C1dIEJ-qVMf-o6Bka9FrFw.text: Great atmosphere and service. Food was just ok. Had the Iberian pork and it was over seasoned. Waiter hyped it up but was just ok.

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States

JFDIRLZxfzPx4rikBU2l4Q.text: The service is excellent and the food is fantastic. I'm not ready to suggest and particular plates yet so I'll have to go a few more times before I suggest what you should order. Everything I had was well worth the price.   Give this plane a try, you won't be disappointed!

bcVng2MIxJQq_wYRIgq-ug.text: I have eaten here three times and it is an excellent choice if you have a refined pallet. If you don't, it is not for you. My 13 year old son found it amazing, but I am a chef so he has quite an extended palette. The food is always great, well developed flavors, perfectly cooked, and great staff. From the moment you walk in to the moment you leave it outstanding. I can't wait to keep coming back. I want to shout out to lip smacking foodie tours for introducing me to this and many other fantastic Vegas restaurants. Sage is great and keep up the out of this world food and staff.

9LeuWpcKVvLIUZVOO515VQ.text: This place is my absolute favorite place to eat on the strip of all time. It is a little pricey, so I must save it for special occasions.  Start your night off with the bubbles drink. If you're a guy, you may not like it, but it is definitely a girls night out dream drink. Champagne with vodka and little bobas. I always have two.  Next, order the hamachi crudo salad. Actually, just order two, because you won't want to share. The fish is perfectly paired with a salad and dressing that I can't even begin to describe. My boyfriend and I used to order the heirloom carrot salad alongside this but they discontinued it. Hopefully they'll bring it back!  For the main dish I highly recommend the venison, shortrib, and any of the fish dishes. So basically, I recommend everything. The chicken and pork are also stellar, just not my cup of tea.   My only complaint is they used to have awesome housemade breads like bacon and cheese and chive, and now all they have is a lame storebought tasting sourdough.   Overall I love this place and will be back!!

0HCEIyO_UP6dyt9EnsWI2A.text: Service was low compare to other restaurant in Las Vegas or anywhere for that fact   Food was ok but not coming back for   Took 30 and my second plate fir them to bright the first drink after I had to stand and complain   I ask to talk to manager and he never came just got 1 free drink ........ really free drink I'm sure that made me happy ...... not   I would pick other restaurant before I pick this one   The best part and what save the night the live music . Great performance and great drink

5ANAP6WXljwsB4B-4z2uBQ.text: This upscale restaurant was kind of like a mixed bag of tricks. We sat down promptly which was a plus but had no menus and water for at least 15 mins. The prices are exorbitant and ridiculous. A bottle of Dom will run you $1000 when on the strip other places were charging half that. The drinks were amazing but we had a wait time on those too. Our waitress kept apologizing for the wait through out the service which we thought was awkward. It was like they knew other tables had priorities and could care less about ours. The food was good but bad service can leave a funky taste in your mouth. The ambience was a little stuffy but the decor is beautiful. Wish we could have had a better experience but glad we check this off our list of Vegas eateries.

79Bny9y2zC96PPOEO35D1w.text: Went here on a whim when other place was too busy. Pleasantly surprised. Unassuming exterior, chill interior. Great food, unique options. Will return.

ODlqPfDch1iu9OENwP8nTQ.text: Sage - is hands down one of my favorite restaurants in Las Vegas. The style of the restaurant and the attention to detail are some of the highlights that keep me going back. I love the rooms there and have always loved the food. It's eclectic and modern, with such a beautiful classic feel to everything they do.   The food is the creation of Chef Shawn McClain. He's man behind the 'Five50 Pizza Bar' also at Aria, and now 'Libertine Social' at Mandalay Bay. Truly an artist.  The tasting menu at Sage is seasonal and every bit delicious. On our most recent trip - we decided to choose from the al a carte menu. It's filled with items that are just too good! We enjoyed beautiful cheese selections, excellent lamb paperdelle and spectacular flavors like the seabass with a pistachio aioli, blood orange puree and watermelon radish. Just too good.   If you get a chance - and please make it available to yourself - get over to Sage and enjoy one of the best meals around.   Happy Eating !   If you're feeling like something decadent and  delicious- the FOIE GRAS candy bar with salted caramel and caramel popcorn, is a fantastic treat.

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Whiskies for days
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Just a pretty view - a crisp glass of Gruner Veltliner and martinis before dinner
Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beautiful little bitters at the Sage bar.

7QanSdh--INwzpWIccd-gw.text: Okay. Yeah. Wow. Such a memorable experience here. AMAZING food and beautiful restaurant. My work hosted a celebratory dinner here and the food, drinks, and service were amazing!

ADsGKhb03Dc46y2LP7aj5Q.text: I must be a pretty awesome sister to have my younger brother treat me to dinner at Sage.  I ordered the $89 tasting menu.    I ordered the following: - Wagyu Beef Tartare - Crushed Caper Aioli, Slow Poached Egg, Crispy Chocolate - Maine Day Boat Scallops - Braised Oxtail, Wild Mushroom, Salted Caramel Reduction - 48 Hour Beef Belly - Grilled Corn, Pickled Pearl Onion, Buckwheat Polenta  AMAZING!

ujhL5iUzQuq7MoTa5njrew.text: My newly acquired taste bud now fancy Foie Gras which was delicately made into a brulee here and served with nice warm amazing fluffy bread! This is a must have dish here at Sage.   The other thing worth mentioning is the fact they change their menu every 2 weeks here! A lot of the new modern restaurants now do that which is impressive as the chef has to constantly think what to put on his new menu. The only downside of this is that I wanted the corn chowder previously pictured on their Yelp and is no longer offered. Wish they had more soup selections overall. Oh and we got the pear salad and it turned out, it wasn't quite a salad as there were maybe 4 leaves on the plate hah - would not recommend if you're going for more of the traditional salad look.   Atmosphere is beautiful and romantic. Nice for a family dinner, a date night, or even an upscale bachelorette dining experience in Vegas.

iDNZCsDAgHwrsOqam3dstg.text: Wanting to try something different, Hubs and I dined here while on a recent trip to The Desert. I must say this place was different...different indeed. We tried the following:  Vancouver Island Kushi Oysters: oysters with Tabasco and Piquillo Pepper (Awesome! Must try as a starter)  Chilled Gazpacho (It was okay)  Wagyu Short Rib: Comes with fennel puree and turnips (Meat was tender. I now know I'm not a fan of fennel nor turnips)  Oh yeah, I can't forget about the bread. They offer bread with bacon bits baked in it. It was really tasty. What a notion!  Summary: I would visit again. The ambiance was incredible. Super swank and romantic. Service was impeccable.

lYPP9Q8O_5Wm4AjG2dIpFw.text: Went here on a Friday night for a birthday dinner. There were 7 of us and they accommodated us very comfortably. The ambience was really chic and the staff was courteous and friendly.   I ordered the wagyu filet and it really was amazing. It was cooked perfectly and the additions on the plate were packed with flavor and complimented the beef well. I also ordered some sort of bacon ravioli dish that was to die for. The desserts were interesting with some flavor combinations I would not have pictured together but somehow it worked.   Each of us ordered a drink, and an entree ranging from 45$-65$. We shared 3 appetizers and total was just under 700$.   I recommend trying out this restaurant if you haven't before. I might go back for a special occasion; however, the restaurant itself did not have any signature items that would really make me want to come back.

photos.caption: Photo of Sage - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Wagyu filet yuuuummm

8KXQPYvFeIx5djkoGyaSPg.text: This was hands down the highlight of our night in Vegas. We were disappointed in the foie gras appetizer though... Even though it's the most popular on the menu. We both love our foie gras pan seared, and this was more of a pate foie gras.... Not our favorite. :( BUT... The scallops I had were absolutely delicious... And my husbands halibut was outstanding. You can't go wrong if you choose either of these entrees.  The dessert was a foie gras 'snicker bar'... It was nice, not outstanding. The presentation of it was beautiful! :-)

x22YpX6_w69-o21xi7rgkQ.text: Amazing ambiance soon as we walked in . We sat down for less than 2 minuets and was greeted by Jason as our server . He was on point throughout our entire dinner and gave amazing customer service . I got the wagyu bone in as my entree and my date got the scallops it was delicious to say the least !! We didn't decide to do desert but Jason surprised us with a unforgettable dessert that finished our evening off with a bang .

PBYCLYcfjvneW4mzLOoqTQ.text: I have had the pleasure of going here about 8 times :))))))))  Somehow, some way...it gets better each time.  This time the chef she made an extraordinary large vegan vegetable medley that was out of this world.   They also made the beet salad and the asparagus salad vegan also.   I could really write a book on this place but my photos do more justice than how I can detail explain everything!   I have several tips...if you are a absinthe drinker get Lucid. I have tried all of them. If you dig a Moscow Mule...get one here because for some reason they are better here than anywhere lol. There wine list on the iPad is AMAZING! If you want a $11,000 bottle of wine...they have it here.  If you are a French Press drinker...I have never asked them what kind of coffee they use but it is super duper yummy.  OH!!!!!!!! I have tried tons of their desserts...unless you are a SAVORY dessert type of person...don't order dessert here. If you like EXTRA SAVORY desserts...then order them here because they are super yummy!!!!!!!

gXFcXoKjHIJZ06oSCfYo3A.text: ***There are a few good things about Shawn McClain's Sage, but it (like a lot of Vegas restaurants) is overpriced and does not deliver the same quality as similar upscale restaurants in cities like San Francisco, Los Angeles and Chicago*** Sage is one of the several upscale restaurants in Aria. Aria's upscale restaurants are much more contemporary than the traditional fine dining spots you will find in older casinos like Caesars Palace and Bellagio. Sage follows that trend. Sage is in a very modern space that has kind of an upscale lounge feel. There is no white tablecloth though the restaurant does feel like a fine dining restaurant when it comes to their menu--a la carte items with premium ingredients, a pre fixe menu and a tasting menu are available. I had the pre fixe menu, which offers the choice of several of Sage's signature dishes across four courses. The meal started with complimentary bread--two crusty options including a bacon roll and salt dusted sourdough. Both breads were fine but nothing special. The amuse bouche was raw tuna with cucumber and wasabi. It lacked the brightness and vibrant flavor of a good amuse. yelp.com/user_local_phot... I started with the foie gras creme brulee, which was a foie gras custard base with a traditional creme brulee caramelized sugar crust. Garnishes included good and sweet Bing cherries as well as warm, buttery and sweet brioche (topped with a little bit of salt). The starter was very dessert-like, but it did have a strong foie gras flavor as well as foie gras' creaminess. The brioche was a little oily. I liked the dish, but I think it would work better as a dessert given its very sweet flavor. yelp.com/user_local_phot... Next came day boat scallops with good mushrooms, greens and braised oxtail. I did like the garnishes. The oxtail was very good--tender, juicy and meaty--though there was too little of it. The scallops were just okay. They just were not as soft, fresh or moist as I have had at other restaurants including Vegas spots like Picasso, Table 10 and Olives. yelp.com/user_local_phot... I had the braised beef belly for my entree. It was an okay tasting dish. The garnishes were decent but not as good as what came with the scallops. The best garnish with this beef dish was the tart pickled ramps, which was the only real flavor that stood out. yelp.com/user_local_phot... The beef belly was like ribs. The beef belly had a good flavor and it was tender and juicy. I did not like the unevenness of it with some meaty parts but also fatty parts that were not rendered down. It could have just been the nature of this cut. Dessert was an almond tart, which was really dense and thick with the texture of a butterscotch square. It was dry and had no cake-like or cream-like consistency. I did not like the core of this dessert though the garnishes of macerated berries and creamy, refreshing and fragrant lavender gelato were both good. yelp.com/user_local_phot... A la carte prices were very high like other high-end Vegas restaurants with entrees in the $40s and $50s. The pre fixe menu was not too bad of a deal given the variety of ingredients and generous portions. Service was good. The staff was attentive and the food came out at a quick pace. Our server had a matter of fact manner (which I liked). It was a little different from the service I have had at similar restaurants where servers tend to be very gracious and eager to please. Even though she did not have that incredibly pleasant approach of those other places, she was still polite, professional and engaging. Overall, the food at Sage was decent and properly cooked though not much about the meal stood out. Though Vegas has a lot of fine dining and upscale restaurants, I actually find it quite hard to have a really great high-end meal in Vegas. If you are looking for really good contemporary upscale cuisine, I recommend the more expensive L'atelier de Joel Robuchon in MGM Grand. If quality of ingredients and good flavors are what you are seeking, I recommend the similarly priced though more formal and traditional Picasso (in the Bellagio) over Sage. Aria, like most casinos on The Strip, offers both complimentary self and valet parking.
